text: admit it because my daughter has a nanny you think i am rich i am not but you are probably as prejudiced as i once was before i hired my nanny it is strange being a working mother there is the compromise between working and looking after your child and the fact that as a parttimer you feel looked down upon by both your employer and stayathome mums then there is the financial side you work but oddly dont see much of your pay before i had my daughter it was simple i worked five days a week and took home five days pay now i work three days a week and take home around one days pay i only get that because my mother is kind enough to look after my daughter one day a week otherwise despite the fact that i enjoy what i do it wouldnt be worth working at all when i read that parents are struggling to afford childcare i nod in recognition this week research from the daycare trust has shown that the cost of a nursery place is rising faster than inflation and now accounts for almost a quarter of the average familys income the average price is a week with those in inner london paying this new research comes on top of another survey showing a dramatic increase in the average earnings of nannies in london for example livein nannies now earn an average salary of more than a year up on a year ago daily nannies meanwhile make on average more than up a more modest this has been interpreted as reflecting a booming economy but i am not convinced surely it is more a case of supply and demand more mothers work so more childcare is needed that means increased demand not only for nannies but nurseries creches and childminders my own scenario seems crazy i pay my nanny out of my taxed income and then as her employer pay her tax and national insurance on top of that the government says it wants to persuade mothers to go back to work but its incentives pointedly dont cover nannies the childcare element of the working tax credit is worth of childcare costs up to a maximum of for a family with one child from employers can also give a week taxfree to every employee to help with approved childcare once again however that means childminders creches and nurseries but not nannies my case is obviously financial madness but we had little choice when my daughter was five months old i began working again initially only a few mornings a week my daughter went to a local childminder and it was all very satisfactory not to mention affordable five months later i got a job with longer hours at exactly the same time my childminder announced that she was giving up due to ill health i rang the local nurseries not only did most of them close between pm and pm totally impractical for a commuter but they also had incredibly long waiting lists in fact my daughter was already down for the only local nursery with longer opening hours she was registered there in april and has not yet been offered a place i investigated different childminders all the recommended ones were booked up but i saw some others i took up a reference for one but was told that although efficient the woman in question wasnt warm or loving others couldnt do the right days or wanted me to pick up my daughter too early in the evening the national childminding association admits that many childminders have long waiting lists and that was my experience i was left with no option but to look for a nanny previously thought of by myself as the preserve of the rich think liz hurley or cherie booth i still find it hard to believe i have one that is not to say that i am unhappy with my choice my nanny is great she comes to my house gives my daughter onetoone attention and doesnt mind staying late if the tubes are delayed but she is also very expensive so what is the solution the government does appear to realise there is a childcare problem but it would help if it could explain exactly what a nanny is the problem is that anyone can call themselves a nanny although many do have nurserynurse or childcare training nannies dont have to have qualifications ours is trained qualified and has more than a decade of experience however when we were looking we were inundated by women with no childcare qualifications they simply liked children and were hoping for an hour childminders must be registered and inspected by ofsted as must creches and nurseries but nannies are completely unregulated and that is why they arent included in the childcare incentives why isnt there a register for nannies whereby their work can be regulated and inspected last year the government via the surestart scheme launched the home carer programme aimed at parents shift workers for example who need someone to look after their child in their own home it only allows nannies to do this if they requalify as registered childminders takeup unsurprisingly has been low and there are just home childcarers however the government is apparently looking into how to extend the scheme to cover people who arent childminders and that may mean nannies according to one welloff friend of mine the best childcare solution is an aupair when i told him we didnt have a spare room he thought for a moment and then told us to get an extension sadly there are no government childcare incentives for building works parentstheguardiancom

text: its a wet morning but the drizzle does not deter the gaggle of mums and their buggies making a beeline for the gate of the corams fields play area in bloomsbury central london the strict rule on the sign explains that no adults are allowed in unless they are accompanied by a child this is not only one of the capitals most popular playgrounds and a rare oasis of open space in a builtup urban area but also one that has been hailed as a national model for its high standards of safety quality and supervision alongside allweather pitches sandpits a cafeteria a paddling pool and fountain as well as swings and slides there is a small farm with resident goats sheep and ducks the area is securely fencedoff from the nearby busy traffic and there are staff in attendance at all times the chair of the corams fields trust which runs the playground is the local mp frank dobson dobson admits it would be difficult to replicate corams fields elsewhere with its thcentury colonnades and the fact that the sites land value alone is estimated at m the playground which first opened its doors in now attracts up to children a day with the compulsory adults in tow of course the former health secretary last week published getting serious about play a review of childrens play designed to establish the principles by which m of lottery cash from the new opportunities fund will be spent it throws down a few challenges to ministers the report recommends that funding should be focused on areas and groups with the poorest access to goodquality play opportunities but with a major emphasis on the inclusion of disabled children who often lose out the review also urges the government to rule out a competitive bidding process which might discriminate against the worstoff councils with the greatest need in a nutshell ministers now have to decide whether to concentrate the money on a limited number of the worstoff areas or to allocate some to every local authority dobson says there are many examples of good practice throughout the country drawing up a national strategy has not been easy because the play needs of children differ from place to place children of different ages want different play facilities successful playgrounds and play schemes vary widely dobsons review reliant to a large degree on work by tim gill director of the childrens play council considered the importance of a variety of local authorityrun facilities from informal play areas and leisure facilities such as skateparks and kickabout areas through to adventure playgrounds and holiday playgroups as well as staffed open access facilities such as corams fields the exercise found patchy provision but in the worst cases identified dangerous and littleused play areas that had fallen into disrepair or were frequented by drugusers and child molesters the report also noted that there was a missed opportunity to make more use of school grounds and buildings which could be opened up more to community use outside school opening hours the publication comes amid growing public concern about levels of obesity among children and even toddlers with poor health caused by lack of exercise and sedentary lifestyles compounded by a poor diet is it any wonder that so many young people are stuck indoors slumped over playstations and computer games when they would be out in the fresh air playing if they had better facilities says dobson parents also want their children to be safe as well as doing more physical exercise a recent mori survey for the audit commission showed that activities for young people was ranked by adults as the single most requested improvement in local services while facilities for young children scored ahead of health education and housing and almost level with crime reduction dobson points to evidence that safer play areas lead to crime reduction he is now seeking guarantees of future funding when the current m pot has run out to reduce dependence upon the lottery cash however dobson wants local proposals to try to maximise the impact of that stream of funding by complementing and augmenting it or meshing it with funds from other sources the reports findings and recommendations will now be scrutinised by the department for culture media and sport as well as other relevant departments notably the department for education and skills education minister cathy ashton is understood to be taking a close interest but the first grants are unlikely to be awarded until next year kids the national disabled childrens charity welcomed the findings of the review but said it was worried about how the pot will be distributed sam brier chief executive of kids commented at present play is simply not an option for most disabled children and they are routinely losing out on all the physical social and developmental benefits that play offers we are however concerned that if the funds are distributed simply on the basis of geographical areas of deprivation many disabled children will once again miss out families of disabled children are predisposed to a greater degree of financial hardship than others irrespective of their geographical location we would therefore like to see the option of some funds being allocated to inclusive play work in every region as dobson emphasises the play lobby is not a particularly vocal one which means that it has never been given high enough priority by local and national decision makers children and young people spend more time at play than taking part in sport or art or cultural activities yet when it comes to funding play lags miles behind though it is not government policy i believe that a commitment to continue lottery funding of play facilities for the next decade would be a great step forward for childrens play and also a sensible and popular use of lottery funds

text: a m scheme to provide childcare in schools all year round was announced today by the work and pensions secretary andrew smith as part of a package of measures to encourage unemployed parents to get a job from april schools in bradford west yorkshire and the london boroughs of haringey and lewisham will provide childcare in term time and during school holidays the pilot projects will also work with job centres to give lone parents extra help finding employment mr smith told a tucdaycare trust conference in london today my aim is that every parent who wants to work should be able to have access to affordable childcare when they need it by making better use of school facilities we can start to make this a reality we will work with local authorities to make sure that school buildings do not stand empty after hours and in the school holidays a scheme providing free childcare to unemployed parents if they get a job will also be piloted in the three areas added mr smith unemployed parents will receive a weeks free childcare if they get work to help them make the transition into employment parents taking advantage of the scheme would not have to take the free childcare in one chunk when they start work but could use individual days to try out different childcare options in advance of taking up a job or to go on training days to boost their chances of finding work said a spokesman for the department for work and pensions dwp around families are expected to benefit over the next two years from the pilot schemes which could be extended nationwide if they prove successful said the dwp single mothers are expected to be the main beneficiaries of the project and the pilot areas were chosen because of the high proportion of lone parents in them the department is in talks with the scottish executive and welsh assembly to identify areas where similar pilots could be carried out the dwp estimates that around jobless lone parents across the country would like to find work the announcement came after the tuc and the trust warned that many women were barred from returning to work because of a lack of affordable childcare their survey of childcare costs in england published yesterday found that a lack of provision was keeping parents and children in large families in poverty yesterdays report said that childcare provision was patchy and expensive preventing many women from returning to work or forcing them to work fewer hours to fit around their arrangements it found that parents paid out bn to day nurseries in with the average price of a nursery place for a child under two costing per week more than in the previous year the reports author bristol academic and childcare expert professor hilary land said while the government should be congratulated for creating thousands of new childcare places its measures to help parents took no account of the extra cost of having three or more children although only a third of all children were in large families of three or more children they accounted for half of all poor children some minority ethnic groups were particularly affected the findings showed nearly a third of pakistani bangladeshi and indian families had three or more children compared with of white families and these groups were more likely to have very low incomes the traditional link between family size and poverty had not been broken said the report the daycare trusts director stephen burke said the government must act to help larger families break this cycle of poverty the tuc general secretary brendan barber added being unable to work because costly childcare remains way beyond the family budget is condemning hundreds of thousands of larger families to a life of poverty

text: we all know that the proper place for injustice is the past when we encounter injustice particularly injustice to women we describe it as victorian medieval or neanderthal depending on the enormity because we are confident that such things are anomalous to our society no group is more confident of this than young women according to a survey conducted by the equal opportunities commission of women aged or under take it for granted that they are paid the same as men with comparable responsibilities and qualifications they are likely to be mistaken officially the average gap between men and womens pay is but there are good reasons to suppose that it might be as wide as this is certainly better than before the equal pay act of when the gap was but clearly not as good as most people assume there are many causes of inequality but one of them argues the eoc is that many women are unaware that they are not earning as much as their male colleagues the same survey discovered that workers of both sexes were surprisingly ignorant of what their colleagues earned maybe because salary has always been an awkward topic of conversation of those surveyed only in social classes a and b knew what their colleagues earned in social class e where traditional good manners evidently hold greater sway the figure was but manners aside it is notable that the better paid are also the better informed and that men are more likely to know what their peers are getting than women are with this in mind the eoc has launched a campaign to encourage women to make comparisons this includes a web page which allows anyone to see how their salary compares with other workers according to region and sector accessible through the eocs website the eoc also advises individuals how to women are still massively underrepresented in positions of influence in business the police media and senior judiciary even though more females are working than ever before research by the eoc reveals that women account for just of the senior judiciary and the senior ranks of britains police forces and of the senior ranks in the armed forces the research said to be the most detailed study of womens representation in senior positions reveals that just of the countrys top business leaders and national newspaper editors are women this is despite the fact that women account for of the workforce and of managers there has been progress assisted by such figures as dame brenda hale appointed a lord of appeal in ordinary last year kate swann the new chief executive of wh smith commander janet williams the new head of scotland yards special branch and barbara cassani the leader of londons olympic bid campaign but too many organisations pay insufficient regard to sexual equality when filling text: mothers should be freed to stay at home longer with their children through a big hike in maternity pay former cabinet minister stephen byers will argue this week too many women are being driven back to the office before they are ready because they cannot afford to live on statutory allowances he will say new mothers get per cent of their salary for the first six weeks dropping to only a week for the rest of their six months maternity leave byerss intervention comes as the government is drawing up a new package of rights for parents downing street will hold a seminar for childcare experts this week crucially ministers are keen to soften their position on working mothers amid arguments that they must not be seen to drive women back to work regardless of their families needs we must give new parents particularly mothers a genuine choice about whether to return to work or stay at home byers will say in a speech to the charity maternity alliance on thursday far too many women are forced through financial pressure to return to work when what they really want is to stay at home and bring up their baby labour is extending choice in areas like health and education it should now do so for new parents he said raising maternity pay to a week for the final weeks close to the minimum wage of could cost up to million a year but would give babies a better start in life debate between working and stayathome mothers has raged for years fuelled by conflicting research on whether children suffer from being looked after by people other than their parents byers said it was not up to politicians to dictate what women did but to provide more options people who are well off have always had that choice he said giving people choice who have never had it is a real political issue for us ministers are now engaging seriously with the sensitive argument about stayathome versus working mothers risking tensions with the treasury which has championed work as the antidote to family poverty harriet harman now solicitor general argued as a backbencher that during the first year of a babys life women should be helped to stay at home if they wanted to while patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary confessed that she regretted working when her children were very small liz kendall director of the maternity alliance said that while the governments investment in childcare for working mothers was welcome it was not helping mothers of young babies they are in danger of being seriously out of step with what most mothers want during the first year of life which is to have the choice to stay at home she said there is a political challenge not to be forced into one box or the other either everybody should be forced to go out to work or everybody should stay at home kendall said the relentless message about work did not reflect research showing that the babys first year of life is the most crucial in developmental terms it is how mothers feel about working that is the key she said if they want to go back to work and they have decent childcare thats good but if theyre forced to work long unsociable hours then if that is combined with poor childcare it can be bad for child text: the nanny state is a strange snobby fusty phrase in the minds of welloff male politicians of the postwar era it was a straightforward sneer nanny was a bossy female authoritarian figure they halfremembered telling them to drink their castor oil and wash behind their ears before bedtime the tens of millions of people for whom state intervention was most needed would have never come across nanny in their lives except perhaps as nan as in granny as for the millions who came across them only through popular culture nannies were mostly a benign fantasy sweetvoiced julie andrews sweeping in with a dose of sugary medicine and a sparkle of magic today apart from the tiny clique of americans and sloane rangers who can afford a norlands gal if nanny conjures up anything it is a keen confused homesick teenager from bratislava despite all this the cobwebbed phrase has stuck with rightwing politicians and commentators like the committee and whipping it is political jargon that has long outlived its origins unlike them it is loaded and always hostile the target is government meddling and interference in private lives and it is interesting that meddling is given a female form the nanny state wears skirts this is a time of year and a moment in politics when the issue of ministerial lectures is particularly timely its hangover time its new year resolution time and boy do the ministers have resolutions for you as the nation groans its way back into work clothes staring aghast at the extra rolling pounds our christmas binge has put on ministers such as tessa jowell are campaigning hard against the impact of the food industry on childrens diets hardly a day passes without new governmentapproved warnings on cholesterol stress sleep sugar and exercise new laws on using mobile phones while driving have come in ministers look on approvingly as the british medical association raises the question of whether there should be a general ban on smoking theres been a salt summit on the use of coronarythreatening quantities of salt in processed foods this is also a time of year when rocketing credit card debt has become a big public issue and yet offers to borrow more money drop through the letterbox daily as britains overweight indebted families look blearily ahead into the government is on hand to teach them family values too a raft of new measures aimed at the parents of antisocial children is now available to the police and courts only yesterday another female minister margaret hodge was being hammered in the papers for approving funds for parentline plus an email advice service for parents the childrens minister argued that good parenting could boost childrens performance at school by more than and that the festive season often highlights family problems and stresses hodges crime according to her critics nannystate meddling increasing interference by the state in peoples everyday affairs it is time to stand up for the nanny state for jowell and hodge and in other areas patricia hewitt and harriet harman and also in general for the states right and duty to involve itself in questions of diet health family budgets and good parenting the crucial point which critics of the nanny state fail to mention is that individuals and families dont stand alone none of us lives in a neutral social space unharassed and free to make wise longterm choices whatever the philosophical ideal in the real world we are bombarded by corporate messages cajoling us and our children to consume and borrow we are inhabitants of the more now spendit eatit society which let us not forget boosts the profits of the multinationals whether we like this way of life or not the consequences are clear america and europe face an obesity epidemic which may shorten the lives of todays children by years as compared to their parents working parents and the decline of the extended family have eroded parenting skills fact the torrent of borrownow propaganda from banks unthinkable a generation ago has resulted in a much more indebted society fact but this is only half the story affluent families have more freedom to deal with the consequences they buy the fresh food which isnt loaded with sugar and salt they buy mounds of expensive fruit for their children they paysubscriptions for gyms and health clubs and go on pricey diets they are bettereducated about health issues and they buy the parenting books they can respond to the latest musthave always a lie advertising for electronic goodies without falling into crippling debt oh yes and they can buy indomestic help nannies and their successors just as in urban america it is the poorer british who are most visibly damaged by the downside of consumerism this is pretty simple if you cant afford the expensive consolations of winter travel or dinners out then the homelier treats of chocolate burgers and alcopops are that much harder to resist fat now means poor pop idols stone michelle is a workingclass girl who stands and wobbles for millions pass a group of kids smoking and the odds are they will be female and poor and if poorer families fall down on the parenting front they cant buy in foreign girls to help plug the gaps who really thinks that a centreleft government should stand aside and do nothing the whole point of progressive politics is to stand with the most vulnerable people today that means helping counter the great commercial shorttermist forces that rain down nanny state once upon a time nannies were the carers and the copers for middleclass families whose parents had opted out today in trying to help all families struggle with consequences of consumerism and social change these ministers are doing a vital and noble job its time their friends on the left gave them some support jackieashleytheguardiancom

text: when you tell the office youre pregnant you hope that your colleagues will share your joy but dont kid yourself their big question will not be about names the sex or whether youve signed up for text: millions of pounds of taxpayers money pumped into expanding childcare facilities for preschool children may have been wasted because much of the new provision is unsustainable the governments spending watchdog warns today in a hardhitting report the national audit office acknowledges the huge strides made by the government through its national childcare strategy but notes that provision is patchy and unaffordable for many families the nao fails to specify how much money has been wasted but reveals that fewer than half of childminders playgroups and day nurseries were currently covering all their costs many providers did not know how many places they had to fill to break even and only half knew what they would do when government startup funding ran out sir john bourn head of the nao said providers needed more training in how to run their businesses so the impressive progress made by this government in creating childcare places could be maintained since the launch of the national childcare strategy in childcare places have been created in england but places have closed the report says some turnover was to be expected but the number of closures was higher than the government had predicted there was also significant regional variation in availability from places per preschool children in the southwest to just in central london the report underlines the huge investment made in childcare from different financial pots in parents spent bn local government bn and the department for education and skills and sure start programme m the childcare tax credit added a further m fulltime care for a child under two now costs families a year up on two years ago the report reveals yet it also points out that cost is not the most important consideration for parents when choosing a childminder playgroup or nursery location reputation quality of staff facilities and opening hours were more important sir john said the government has made impressive progress in creating new childcare places and in providing early education for preschool children since but not enough of these new places are yet in deprived areas where they would most benefit children and parents the governments investment will be wasted if the new provision is not viable more training is needed especially for childminders and providers need more support to help them manage their businesses the conservative mp edward leigh chairman of the commons public accounts committee said access to good childcare was vital but he was very concerned that new childcare places are being created willynilly with no real idea of how they are going to be sustained in the future the childrens minister margaret hodge said weve come a long way since the introduction of the firstever national childcare strategy we need to do more but its important to recognise the progress that has been made in a relatively short space of time further progress has been achieved since this report was compiled the latest figures show that there are now more childcare places than there were in back in there was only one childcare place for every nine children and there is now one place for every five children the tuc called on employees to support a day of action against britains longhours culture by starting work at the proper time today taking a lunch break and leaving on time writes john carvel the first work your proper hours day was organised after union leaders found employees were putting in unpaid overtime worth bn a year an average of each this was equivalent to everyone working for nothing from the start of the year until now brendan barber the general secretary said we are not saying that we should become a nation of clockwatchers but we do work the longest hours in europe and the biggest growth has been among people doing unpaid overtime

text: more than women a year take legal action claiming they have been sacked for being pregnant the equal opportunities commission said yesterday in an analysis of discrimination in england and wales the first national investigation concluded that victimisation was rife it led to depression among women and unnecessary loss of skills for their employers even the system designed to give redress was itself discriminatory average compensation awarded to women for injury to feelings after dismissal for being pregnant was lower than for dismissals for other reasons the time limit for making a claim of pregnancy discrimination was three months obliging women to lodge their complaint during the later stages of pregnancy or soon after birth when they were least likely to want confrontation julie mellor the commissions chairwoman said tribunal cases were the tip of the iceberg its helpline received more calls from women on problems related to pregnancy at work than any other subject it reported that many companies saw an employees pregnancy as a warning of difficulties in future one woman told the commission my employer told me that getting pregnant is disgusting and that im obviously not careerminded another said i work for an organisation that seems to believe having a day off for a hangover is pretty macho but having a day off for morning sickness is a pain in the neck i call the place jurassic park a third said im being picked on persistently my immediate line manager has suggested that im screwing the company and that i used a table in the meeting room to lie down on if i was tired ms mellor said with the average cost of replacing one member of staff amounting to the economy and individual employers themselves simply cannot afford to lose valuable skilled staff just because they are pregnant the research showed the usual pattern was for women to be dismissed before going on maternity leave sometimes within hours or days of informing the employer they were pregnant the commission says just over of women aged to are pregnant at any one time and just over half are employees this suggests about employees are pregnant at any one time maternity leave entitlement is higher in britain than in most eu countries but maternity pay is among the lowest

text: victims of around million crimes do not get the support they need due to lack of funding the national charity for people affected by crime announced today victim support responsible for the majority of the nations services to victims and witnesses says more funds and volunteers are urgently needed to keep up with growing demand its report vision is published today to mark victim support week and the charitys th anniversary support networks are unavailable to victims of unsolved crimes as well as to those of racist sexual or domestic offences who fear reprisals if they go to the police only three out of people who reported crimes see their case go to court the charity has identified three new initiatives it has developed but cannot offer for lack of funding a programme to help young victims of crime would cost m a year a national recruitment and training programme for volunteers to support those affected by rape and sexual assault would cost to pay for a domestic violence development worker in every county or city would cost m victim support said these are services which we have developed but we cant properly roll them out because we havent got the funds with trained volunteers and employees victim support runs its witness service in every criminal court it receives m a year in funding from the government which represents just for every of public money spent on the criminal justice system it helps around million people a year the chief executive of victim support dame helen reeves said the government deserves to be congratulated for its work in ensuring that victims and witnesses will receive better treatment in the criminal justice system we lobbied for this to happen and it is a very positive result in our short history but society as whole including the media local government and the public services now need to change their agendas and recognise that the effects of crime if neglected can do untold damage to individuals families and to entire communities victim support has achieved a great deal but with more support we could improve the lives of many of those who now struggle to cope with the devastating effects of crime alone the home office said we welcome victim supports endorsement of the work the government has been doing to improve the experiences of victims and witnesses using the criminal justice system

text: it has six bedrooms two bathrooms picturesque views across the cumbrian hills and can offer bed and breakfast accommodation for one night or full board for a week need an early morning call in the morning sir no problem want something special for dinner thats not on the menu madam the fulltime housekeeper will get on to it straight away it has kitchens and staff quarters to satisfy every whim of the guests it can cater for a hotel by any other name for children in less than four weeks jumping jacks playcentre in the rural market town of wigton could become the first nursery in the uk to offer hour care for children parents who use the centre can expect to pay an hour for leaving a child overnight the hour care for children aged months to years has been in the planning stages for nearly a year and is an ofsted inspection away from opening all the building work on the centre has been completed and the final decorating work on the six bedrooms is nearly finished the bunk beds are in place with three blue rooms for the boys and three pink ones for the girls it has already taken bookings for the months ahead and if the ofsted inspection goes well and staff are confident it will the centre will open for business on march jane crawford manager of jumping jacks is aware of the controversy the centre could cause is it ever right to leave your kids at a nursery for days on end but in defence of the decision to offer hour care she points out that it is just good business sense creating a service to satisfy demand when we first came up with the idea a lot of the parents who use the centre now were very interested says crawford we have a lot of shift workers in the wigton and surrounding rural area a lot of people are parents who have to work night shifts one week and a different shift the next week there are also nhs workers in cumbria who work different shift patterns and then of course there are the emergency services there is a lot of demand for something like this in our area crawford believes any parent in britain who works shifts will be hoping and praying for a similar centre in their area it can be an absolute headache trying to juggle the demands of work and parenting were just hoping to be of assistance in that headache some businesses in britain can offer nightcare to staff on an emergency basis but the difference here will be that we will be able to offer this service to anyone who needs it at present the playcentre has a baby unit a day nursery an outofschool club and a youth centre it also has breakfast clubs and holiday clubs catering for up to children if the expansion plans go ahead it could have nearly children on its premises at any one time hours a day crawford says the centre has the extra staff in place to deal with any eventuality weve been working very closely with ofsted to make sure we meet all the regulations regarding safety issues we have six rooms so we can separate children of different ages all the menus have to be nutritional and pass strict inspections were going to have a good range of meals well be having all the usual food children love shepherds pie chips that type of thing but there will also be an emphasis on healthy meals too if a child has any special dietary requirements we can also cater for that staff and management are sensitive to the charge that jumping jacks is just a childrens hotel parents could come here and book their children in for a week while they go off to spain or whatever but thats not something we can do a lot about were a business offering a service and the parents who use the centre are our customers thats all crawford says the main reason the centre is offering care for up to seven days is for parents who have specialneeds children and need some respite care again a few of the parents who already use our facilities for their specialneeds child at present are very interested in placing their children within the new centre having a disabled child or specialneeds child can be absolutely exhausting for the parents the centre will be somewhere for the child to stay while the parent or parents can have some time on their own lesley dixon is a childcare worker from wigton who says the centre is a godsend her nineyearold daughter lauren has cerebral palsy and she plans to use the overnight care one weekend a month i think this is a wonderful idea and i believe it can offer a service to someone like me that is invaluable i have another daughter kimberley who is and this will allow me to spend more time with her too lauren attends the centre at present and loves the place well try it out for one weekend a month and see how it goes as well as the support from parents the centre has also received state funding of the total cost of the project is coming from the new opportunities fund but such enthusiasm is far from universal stephen burke director of daycare trust expresses his concerns this centre is clearly responding to a need in the area it will serve but our main concern would be that staff at the centre are able to provide highquality care that is suitable for the children and care that the parent can be happy with however rather than seeing more of these centres in the uk we would prefer the government to introduce better homebased care for example nannies who can stay overnight which is something im sure most parents would prefer too crawford though is passionate that jumping jacks is answering a common need i think people are finally waking up to the fact that the traditional way of working nine to five monday to friday mum at home and dad at work is over being flexible is something employers are demanding more and more parents have been aware of this for a long time and have had to struggle through trying to maintain that elusive worklife balance everyone is beginning to wake up and realise those stereotypes are finally over andrew martindale and his wife kathryn are typical of the parents jumping jacks aims to attract andrew works shifts as a train driver while his wife is an auxiliary nurse in the nhs the couple have two children ryan nine and caitlin five in this day and age parents cant just be parents they also have to be breadwinners says andrew its not the way many parents would want it but its the way it is both kathryn and i work very strange shifts and trying to arrange cover can be quite difficult obviously the children come first but we have to earn as well i think its a brilliant idea and believe more and more of these centres will open up before too long its fine if you have lots of family support to be able to cope with the unexpected changes on shifts but if you dont then something like this can make your life so much better whether its a childrens hotel or a hour child centre crawford believes that while jumping jacks may be the first such establishment in the uk it will not be the last we are confident that roundtheclock care will prove to be very popular here she says im just amazed that no one has thought of it before i wouldnt be surprised if in a few years time theres one of these on offer in every town and city in britain

text: when a report on domestic violence was published last week harriet harman sounded much like every vexed feminist has sounded for the past years in the study of nearly reported cases of domestic violence only per cent had ended in successful prosecution per cent had gone to court half hadnt even been recorded by the police we need to make sure men know they will be prosecuted and sent to prison the solicitor general urged police policy is now to prosecute she assured us but its a question of getting the message through to officers on the ground sending offenders to prison would have a real effect on the prevalence of domestic violence she said this prediction has been an article of feminist faith for as long as i can remember we have insisted that the only way to stop men beating their partners is to bring the full vengeful force of the law down on their heads and we have been reciting statistics for decades by now few people can be unaware that one in four women will become a victim that two women are killed by their partner or ex every week or that more than a quarter of all reported violent crime is by men against women at home making domestic violence the second most common violent crime the solution to a crime this serious would have to be found within the criminal justice system it seemed perfectly obvious in this instance if in no other prison would work but what if it turned out not to its an unthinkable proposition but as harman said herself a policy of prosecution does now apply the expression just a domestic hasnt summed up senior police attitudes for years the piteous per cent conviction rate has to be explained somehow harman chooses to blame the legal system for failing to put its policy into practice across the board but in last weeks study the problem with almost half the cases which reached the cps was that the victim withdrew her complaint we could say it was because she mistrusted the system we could put it down to fear or ignorance or any number of feminist rationalisations available to account for this unexpected turn of events where the women turn out to be more problematic than the police but there would have to come a point where we accepted the victims feelings if women keep saying they do not want a punitive policy to insist that one works becomes meaningless i spent some time last year in a domestic violence cid unit in londons paddington green station it was staffed by highly motivated specially trained detectives they were clever and ambitious they wanted convictions and most of the time to their intense frustration they could not get them it drove them mad the reason they couldnt put violent men in prison was that the victims didnt want them to the modern solution is what police call victimless prosecutions increasingly they will try to gather enough evidence to secure a conviction without her testimony the logic is neat if the weak link is the victim then get rid of her victimless prosecutions are supposed to be in the womens interests unfortunately some of the women i met through paddington green didnt agree in fact they were quite annoyed the police couldnt always comprehend these womens maddening reluctance to put their partners in prison and so the women began to be perceived as part of the problem an ungrateful obstructive nuisance some of the officers seemed angrier with the victims than they were with the men who beat them up it is easy to see how their sympathy could dissolve into irritation but it is hard to see this as a feminist victory or as progress the presumption behind victimless prosecutions is that these women need their consciousness raising that they are too frightened or diminished to know whats good for them so the court will decide but a policy which assumes that the police are right and battered women are wrong is a perplexing triumph for feminism tony blair has described harriet harmans forthcoming domestic violence bill as a symbol of our determination to rebalance the whole criminal justice system around the needs of the victim given more time and more legislation perhaps prosecutions will begin to work but the wait cannot be limitless an american academic linda g mills wrote a book last year called insult to injury rethinking our response to intimate abuse half of all partners of violent men never leave she reasoned those that do go will return to the man beating them on average five times before leaving for good few want their childrens father locked up what most of them want according to mills is the man they love to stop beating them up mills wants couples to be brought into therapy instead of court if they are helped to understand the dynamics of intimate violence she believes they might be able to stop it a pilot project in canada looks promising but policy in britain is to exclude from couple counselling any couple where the man has been violent it is a curious situation that once a woman has been beaten she is denied the support that might save her relationship and her life so everything is left to the police after demanding so much of them you might say it was churlish or at least impatient to start wondering whether they really are the answer even raising the doubt risks reviving the despicable old suspicion that hitting your wife isnt really a crime and the police are worn out indignant the morning after an attack a paddington detective officer complained well call the victim up and suddenly were the troublemakers i say next time you could be in a coffin but no one can believe that their husband will kill them next time she could be in a coffin if one day we have to change our minds about how to defeat domestic violence we had better be willing because we do not have all the time in the world

text: speculation about a new policy from the conservative party to pay stayathome parents an allowance report february has prompted a welcome debate about the kind of support parents need our society has changed almost beyond recognition over the past years in of couples both partners now work dads are doing between a quarter and onethird of parental childcare and without the unpaid work of over million carers britain would be facing an increase in the socialcare bill of billions of pounds but both employment and social policy have failed to adapt to these profound changes the challenge now for all parties is to develop measures that would genuinely give all parents and carers men as well as women wider choices about whether to work stay at home or combine both options at different stages of their lives at the moment many get a raw deal if they choose not to work the contribution they make to our society is not valued and they receive inadequate financial and other support if they go out to work their opportunities are often limited because of a lack of flexibility about working arrangements they dont have access to affordable childcare or social care and they are less able to make pension contributions twice as many women as men rely on meanstested benefits in retirement increased flexibility at work backed up by affordable professional care would help to give mothers fathers and carers more choice there is also a desperate need for new measures to boost womens retirement income this is a political issue that has finally come of age jenny watson deputy chair equal opportunities commission

text: parents who separate will be expected to agree parenting plans that give generous time with the children for both mother and father under government proposals to cut the number of bitter and protracted court battles over child contact the early intervention project to be piloted this year aims to bring parents together from the point of separation and help them to reach agreement the idea modelled on successful schemes in the us and canada is to help parents deal with the anger left over from their failed relationship which can get in the way of future cooperation they will be taught how to handle the problems of postdivorce parenting and told of the psychological harm that parental battles or being deprived of one parent can do to their children parents will be presented with a framework or plan for future contact arrangements which they will be expected to comply with the move a joint initiative of the department for constitutional affairs dca and the department for education and skills follows a growing acceptance by judges and ministers that the current system for resolving contact disputes is failing children and parents figures show that as many as of divorced fathers lose contact with their children stunts by angry fathers dressed as action figures scaling bridges and buildings have moved the issue up the agenda in the past few weeks activists from fathers justice have staged protests in london bristol newcastle upon tyne and liverpool police closed the clifton suspension bridge in bristol when four protesters dressed as batman robin superman and spider man scaled it this month on the same day two fathers demonstrating on a gantry at the entrance of the blackwall tunnel in south london were arrested and further protests were staged on bridges above the a a m and a in london an appeal court judge lord justice wall said in a recent judgment the court system for dealing with contact disputes has serious faults it tends to entrench parental attitudes rather than encouraging them to change it is illadapted to deal with the difficult human dilemmas involved notably when it comes to the enforcement of its orders the early intervention scheme is supported by judges including englands senior family judge dame elizabeth butlersloss president of the high courts family division lord filkin the family law minister in the dca has met representatives of fathers groups including sir bob geldof who is supporting their cause a spokesman for the dca said the government has been looking closely at early intervention pilots and will be coming forward with proposals that involve better education information and support for families in the near future the interests of the child remain paramount wherever it is safe to do so we want the child to have meaningful contact with both parents hamish cameron a leading child psychiatrist who backs early intervention said the problem is always that the husbandwife argument spills over into the motherfather argument in divorce its even more important to keep those two roles separate thats what early intervention does it saves court time it saves money and children get good postdivorce parenting oliver cyriax of the social policy thinktank new approaches to contact said the project could potentially have a huge impact with sound management it has every chance of success jack osullivan of fathers direct said his group had been urging the government to pilot such a scheme its very important to take parents who are in conflict out of an adversarial system so you can get speedier resolution and more focus on the needs of children and a resolution which will involve both parents spending plenty of time with the children

text: violent men are to be sent to americanstyle classes on how to treat women under a nationwide programme to reduce domestic violence the training will challenge male stereotypes of nagging wives or a womans proper role in the home and teach alternatives to coercive dominating violent behaviour it will aim to prevent abusive men attacking future partners or taking revenge on former wives past victims will be interviewed and offered advice on protecting themselves and their children the first nationwide approved programme to be introduced in april is based on one developed in duluth minnesota men will have weekly sessions for up to months on everything from sexual respect to how violence affects children and why the victim cannot be blamed for an assault its about not making excuses for choices you make and for behaving in an unacceptable way said nicola harwin of the charity womens aid who is trained in the method used in duluth its not the fact she is on at you to do the housework its about men being responsible for their violence a home office spokeswoman said the classes for offenders were seeking to protect future victims of domestic violence as well as the current known victims the results of pilot schemes in west yorkshire and london were encouraging but the home office says it is too early to draw firm conclusions about reconviction rates and harwin cautions against seeing the classes as a panacea the duluth programme was credited with cutting deaths from domestic violence in some us cities but harwin says spouses who stayed with their partners hoping the programme would change them were often disappointed the projects founders estimated that fewer than half of the men stopped physically attacking their partners and of those very few stopped being psychologically abusive harwin said what we have to be clear about to women is that there is no guarantee it will make him change and no guarantee it will protect your safety

excessive drinking and admits to occasional amphetamine and cocaine use when she was she was arrested and charged with assault after a fight with a girl outside a pub at she was charged with burglary text: as professor higgins wondered in my fair lady why cant a woman be more like a man now it seems some have answered his call and ditched sugar and spice in favour slugs and snails latest figures from the learning and skills council lsc out this week reveal that young women are starting to muscle in on traditional jobs for the boys almost a quarter of all new modern apprentices signing up to join the metal industry are girls the new figures also show that celeb status and the success of designers like giorgio armani and john galliano is drawing young males to take up apprenticeships in the textile industry in fact over threequarters of apprentices are men in search of catwalk glory however the lsc data showing the top ten most popular apprenticeships reveals a more traditional gender divide among young people making their career choices overall women appear to be reluctant to strut their stuff on scaffoldings with less than signing up for an ma in building and construction in the male dominated employment sectors of engineering and manufacturing automotive and electronics boys made up more than of apprentices signing up to earn and learn with top industrial companies conversely hairdressing health and social care and business administration remain a female preserve in these jobs women dominated the category making up more than of the successful mas in each sector that said industries such as hospitality and retailing are beginning to show almost total sexual parity in particular the continued growth of the hospitality industry has led to an upsurge in the numbers of boys eager to sign up with almost of the mas in the sector taken up by males gaynor field head of modern apprenticeships programme at the lsc england says modern apprenticeships are all about choice and ensuring that young people have the opportunity to reach their full potential in their chosen career mas aim to offer a viable vocational route to success regardless of gender with more than different mas currently available in more than sectors the opportunities to combine on the job learning earning and gaining a nationally recognised qualification have never been wider since more than young people have committed to an ma programme and last year alone young people joined the scheme to build a brighter career for themselves and helping to stem the productivity losses suffered by uk businesses through the skills shortage by the end of this year the government aims to steer of young people between the ages of and to start a modern apprenticeship for the first time modern apprenticeships are all about providing young people with learning options beyond the traditional gcses and a levels route say its supporters apprentices undertake on the job training with a suitable employer whilst studying for a nationally recognised qualification such as an national vocational qualification nvq the majority of mas are paid a wage for the job they are doing others will receive a training allowance of at least a week however many mas receive an additional topup payment at the discretion of their employer the learning and skills council lsc has set up dedicated helplines young people interested in taking up a modern apprenticeship can contact the lsc on wwwrealworkrealpayinfo employers who are keen to take on apprentices should contact the lsc on

text: working parents face rocketing bills for registered childcare with the costs of nurseries childminders and afterschool clubs in england rising by more than inflation for the third year running according to a national survey from charity daycare trust for middle income parents it looks like the situation is going to get worse if plans announced by the government this week get the goahead margaret hodge minister for children said middle income parents who take advantage of allday childcare at state nurseries should cough up for half of the cost a parent who opts for a am to pm state nursery place will pay for half a day and if the childcare tax credit is anything to go by parents who have a joint income of about or over will be forced to pay in most situations where both parents work they are unable to take advantage of state nurseries instead they must look to the private sector for childcare a fulltime nursery place for a child under two now costs an average of a week almost a year thats up on last years figure and equates to nearly a quarter of the average household income of a week the typical cost of a fulltime place with a registered childminder for a child under two is a little cheaper at a week while for children aged two and over a place costs on average at nurseries and with a childminder for older children hours a week at an after school club typically costs the highest nursery cost identified in the survey was a week the costs are such that a working couple with for example a oneyear old and a three yearold in fulltime nursery places would face an annual childcare bill of if they live in the northwest while their counterparts in the southeast would pay daycare trust says that parents pay threequarters of the cost of childcare with the government paying most of the rest plus a small contribution from employers in parents in britain paid bn to the day nursery industry daycare trust director stephen burke says parents in britain already pay the highest childcare bills in europe they tell us they cannot afford to pay more affordable childcare for all is crucial to tackle child poverty to help parents work and train and to raise educational attainment quality childcare helps give children a good start in life the government needs to help all families access quality affordable childcare near where they live in the short term daycare trust is calling on the government to increase help for working parents through improving the childcare tax credit this is a benefit an element within the working tax credit available to households earning up to where parents both in a couple work at least hours a week and who pay for some form of registered childcare it can provide help with up to of your childcare costs the percentage you get depends on your income subject to maximum limits on the weekly costs you can claim for if you pay for care for one child the weekly limit on costs is so the maximum you can receive at is a week if you pay for care for two or more children the weekly limit is and therefore the maximum you can claim is daycare trust points out that working families on lower incomes who get help through the childcare tax credit still have to find at least of the cost of childcare and there is no extra help for families with three or more children using childcare the current average award through the childcare tax credit is only a week so the charity wants to see improvements to the tax credit acknowledging that parents with two or more children using childcare face double or more costs increasing the percentage of costs covered by the tax credit increasing the level of childcare costs covered to reflect the real costs parents pay reducing the hours the second earner in a couple has to work to qualify for the tax credit the charity says the government must subsidise places so that every family can access quality childcare at a price they can afford by having a generous parental and maternity pay and leave systems if the government is to meet its target of abolishing child poverty in a generation daycare trust and the tuc say it must aim for a system of childcare whereby all women in training education or employment can have access to affordable childcare

text: despite the fact that almost babies are born in the uk each year many employers still struggle to treat mothers fairly when they are pregnant and when they return to work as a result many women end up badly off financially accepting demotion poorer pay and even unfair dismissal if they knew their rights however they might put up more of a fight last april new rights were introduced allowing most female employees to extend their six months maternity leave entitlement to up to a year before returning to the same post but employment specialist michael burd of solicitor lewis silkin believes many bosses will struggle to deal with the qualitatively different challenge of a years absence its going to be a big issue he says employers will be denying people the right to return and getting themselves into all sorts of trouble we will start seeing how employers are responding from april when the first mothers who took a year off begin returning to work a lot of discrimination already takes place against pregnant women and new mothers according to the maternity alliance one problem is that many women do not know their rights the rule of thumb is that you have the right to return to your previous role and the same terms and conditions you enjoyed says rachael maskell equal opportunities officer of the union amicus if the job is still there the individual does have the right to go back to it adds sarah king legal officer at maternity alliance there is a partial getout for employers who must reserve the job for the new mother unless this is not reasonably practicable but maternity alliance says this getout applies only if the job no longer exists in which case the woman should be offered a very similar role or dismissed following proper procedures including consultation seeking alternative work and redundancy pay if these procedures were not followed its likely there would be grounds for discrimination and unfair dismissal claims through an employment tribunal common problems seen by maternity alliance include someone being replaced by the person who did the maternity cover or finding that colleagues have been promoted above them but king says women have strong clear rights in these situations often employers say we found that it works better with your replacement in the job or your replacement is better in the job than you are that is neither here nor there the individual does have the right to go back into the job similarly if colleagues have been promoted over a womans head in her absence she has a potential sex discrimination claim if she was not informed about the promotion possibility and invited to go for it too there is a fairly easy way of reducing problems says burd of lewis silkin most responsible employers have realised that they put themselves in the best possible position by maintaining a communications line with the person who is off if new mothers still receive newsletters and other communications have the option to do training and discuss arrangements for their return well in advance the chances of problems developing are much reduced julie mellor chair of the equal opportunities commission advises any individual can write to their employer saying they want to be kept in touch and saying the way they would prefer to do that when i was in this position i found it really difficult to take phone calls but newsletters can help and access to websites or trade publications on returning to work mothers also have the right to ask for though not necessarily to get a change in their working arrangements such as parttime working and it is not all bad news maskell of amicus says some employers are fantastic and do all they can maternity alliance advice line equal opportunities commission

text: i belong to a club that no parent would ever voluntarily join membership requires appearance in the family courts after failing to reach an agreement with a former spouse or partner about your children if your partner is making what you consider to be unreasonable demands over contact and doesnt agree to mediation tough you might find yourself as i did in front of a judge who will not only capriciously impose his ideas about suitable arrangements for your children on you but feel free to make personal comments after dismissing me as a bitter and overanxious mother my barrister assured me that if the judge passed me on the street later that day he wouldnt have a clue who i was it wasnt personal but there is little more personal than a complete stranger with the power to pass judgment on your parenting dictating how much time you spend with your children once laid down in a legal document these arrangements are hellishly difficult to change unless you can come to an arrangement with your by now deeply estranged partner everyone loses especially the children after the eviscerating experience of costly court proceedings it may take years to rebuild some fragile trust with the other parent who will have his own frustrating and humiliating tale to tell that is why it came as a crushing blow last week when the government appeared to reject an opportunity to bring real reform to the family court system the department for education and skills introduced family resolutions pilots aimed at diverting warring parents from the courts by encouraging them to use mediation services and parenting classes launched in london brighton and the north east the scheme will run for a year it sounds great in principle but look at the detail and weep mediation is not mandatory and since it offers no workable guidelines on contact this freeforall could easily flounder mediation already exists but will always have a limited function until it operates in the shadow of the law unless parents know what sort of orders the courts are liable to make anyone can quit mediation to gamble that the courts will take their side the new scheme gives parents in conflict little incentive to take up its woolly offer to make matters worse family justice minister lord filkin before handing the scheme to the dfes had been considering one modelled on north american practices the early interventions project which would have delivered dramatic change called for mandatory parenting classes where couples who had applied for residents orders would within weeks have to hammer out workable arrangements parents would only have to face a judge if they could not come to an agreement in florida where a similar scheme has been run since the early s the number of parents in court has plummeted moreover the government body charged here with running the pilot project is one that has historically opposed the principle of guidelines on contact the children and family court advisory and support service cafcass which currently makes recommendations on orders in disputed cases has been widely criticised by parents groups for its intransigence steve fitzgerald chair of the coalition for equal parenting which backed the early interventions project describes cafcass as a discredited organisation that has hijacked the project on the pretext that it is against the interests of the child i cannot believe that the department for education and skills has funded them to get on with the job he says oliver cyriax who helped devise early interventions says in the space of a few weeks cafcass has managed to vandalise a major reform it took hundreds of professionals eight years to agree leading child development specialists now agree on a childs general need for contact with both parents while cafcass operates on the assumption that every case is different today the coalition for equal parenting will meet shadow ministers dominic grieve and tim loughton to request crossparty support on an earlyday motion which would back the principles of the early interventions scheme as the number of court applications soars there has been a increase over the past five years and fathers groups plan further actions of civil unrest this is an issue that will not go away meanwhile real reform cannot come too soon for those of us in this the misery club

text: last weeks budget saw a longawaited breakthrough in tax relief for childcare from next april working mothers can opt to be paid up to per week in childcare vouchers which will be exempt from tax just as they are already exempt from both employers and employees national insurance contributions the governments record on tax allowances for child care has been good in its first budget it made the use of workplace creches a taxfree benefit inhouse creches are still relatively rare however and last weeks change extends the benefit to parents who have to make more flexible arrangements the vouchers can be used to pay for childcare within the home as well as outside to au pairs nannies and even relatives but not partners so the beneficiaries include middle class parents and all those who earn too much to qualify for working tax credits many parents will no doubt feel that a taxfree is not enough but the change itself is an important concession from the treasury and the inland revenue what has always been the issue is that money paid for childcare is money taxed twice once when earned by the parent and childcare is usually paid out of the mothers salary and again when the carers income is taxed last years working tax credits were introduced for parents on low incomes as an incentive to get single parents off benefits childcare vouchers make tax relief on childcare available to all workers the vouchers were originally launched in the late s the conception of anne ross now corporate business manager at accor who told me that she only began the project because she over estimated the initial demand the original idea was that the childcare voucher was to be as simple as the luncheon voucher which used to be widely issued by firms who did not provide their workers with office canteens ross persisted with her idea and today the childcare voucher is the most popular method by which employers contribute to childcare the vouchers are a commercial venture but without rosss lobbying its unlikely that either employers or the government would have adopted this method of contributing to childcare

text: it is to be honest the trouble with men our inarticulacy our abject failure to explain our joy or capture our pain to let our humanity hang out and when love goes wrong nothing including its politics goes right for us then there is pain without gain then we are not mr big but mr puny so this week vociferous fathers who want to share their children are bitterly disappointed what do they demand their rights their designated half of their own kids what did they get from margaret hodge the minister for children just the chance of a little nambypamby no teeth afteryouclaudette mediation climb more cranes lads this dads army is getting desperate and of course we fortunate noncombatants need to recognise that no grief comes more raw than the icy tide that flows through the family courts too many divorces can turn visceral in a trice and slide into sheer bloodymindedness its an area the nanny state can barely reach but at least if we stop shouting for a minute we may almost hear ms hodge thinking the modest proposal for her to decide on remember was whether as in florida couples resolved to break up and fight out their custody battles in the courts here should first be required to go through a mediation procedure that spells out the sort of typical settlement a judge would anyway impose at the end of a long costly day access for dad granted on a generous scale and written into parenting plans the court could cite if one partner or another disregarded them firm tough stuff what no litigation the notion almost uniquely came backed by an influential collection of judges solicitors and legal campaigners lawyers voting for no delays and no fees put turkeys and christmas to shame for once though the disinterested parties seemed to be putting the interests of the children first but ms hodge hasnt gone the whole hog the necessity of mediation is there for the first time in her new policy she wants to sort things out but somewhere on its route through whitehall a few battles seem to have been lost the mediation she envisages wont come with plans and possible sanctions attached nor will it rely on any template settlements these will be quieter gentler discussions not virtual arbitrations and thus perhaps more flappy febrile stuff how cross can you get about that very cross indeed it is described as doomed to failure as cynical and an absolute sham spiderman wont be trading his fathers justice membership cards yet lets for the time being treat it as development work in progress lets put the big issues on the line in a world where carrie has just departed her city tv sex life six series and separate screen affairs later where blame is just as confusing as ulrika jonssons election as celebrity mum of the year consider the familiar wreck of a partnership are men the problem or the solution it is impossible to generalise or to keep emotion out of either reckoning existing law perhaps reflecting older assumptions takes the problem route it is in practice weighted on the womans side but men increasingly may be part of the solution too you can count around million children in britain who come from a home with no father you can calculate that over of them see their fathers less than once a fortnight and that have no contact at all you can also collate researches and prove that in general though not in particular children who see both parents regularly are probably cleverer happier and more stable dads on such figures arent an optional extra dads make a difference in the only arena that matters the one where children come first but how do we make kids our priority whatever the noises off is that something that whitehall can ordain two things stand out from the sad screaming history of the last few years one is pretty obvious
