text: measures unveiled by the government yesterday to try to divert separated parents from bitter court battles over their children were condemned by fathers groups as doomed to failure fathersjustice the group whose stunts have paralysed traffic around the country pledged to step up its campaign for a better deal for separated fathers pilot schemes to encourage warring parents to resolve contact disputes by mediation will be launched in london brighton and sunderland from next september but fathers organisations predicted that the scheme would fail and criticised the decision not to go ahead with a pilot more closely modelled on a successful early intervention scheme in florida and other us states the department of constitutional affairs had been consid ering a scheme modelled on one which has dramatically cut the number of court cases in florida judges lawyers and other professionals had consulted for three years and come up with a plan under which parents would be presented with sample parenting plans with an assumption of generous time with the children for both mother and father instead the more ad hoc family resolution scheme favoured by the department for education and skills will go ahead parents who apply to court for contact orders will be encouraged to go to mediation to try to agree their own arrangements within two weeks instead of waiting weeks for a court hearing but mediation is voluntary and unless both parents agree it will not take place tony coe president of the equal parenting council said the initiative was doomed to failure and parents should have a legal presumption of contact with their children he added it isnt going to make as far as we can see any practical difference we need simplicity so everybody knows the moment they go to court the court is going to be aiming towards a shared parenting plan unless there is a genuine reason why that should not take place if a parent is violent or abusive mediation is all well and good and we are all supportive of mediation but it is of no value if you dont have the authority of the court behind it the minister for children margaret hodge and the family justice minister lord filkin also announced an additional m for child contact services including funding of new contact centres and the introduction of new forms to ensure judges are aware of accusations or incidents of domestic violence at the start of cases jim parton of families need fathers described the family resolution scheme as watered down and ineffectual fathers justice whose members dress as superheroes to stage protests on cranes said the pilot was cynical and an absolute sham matt oconnor the groups founder said from our point there are no good points he added that to make matters worse the children and family court advisory and support service cafcass would be involved in administering the scheme cafcass was heavily criticised by the commons constitutional affairs committee last year it found there were serious failings in the organisation which was unable to cope with the demand for its services a spokesman for the department for education and skills stressed the scheme was a pilot which would be evaluated after a year the initiative was welcomed by relate and by the solicitors family law association which advocates mediation in disputes

text: domestic abusers are much more likely to commit other crimes but police are failing to make crucial connections according to metroplitan police research a study of offences and perpetrators mostly men discovered that at least of those who had physically assaulted partners had a criminal history around one in had sexual convictions or there was intelligence that they had been been involved in other rapes or sexual assaults of those who had sexually abused a partner one in four were committing offences outside the home and one in eight were considered highly dangerous yet only of those who had raped or sexually assaulted a partner were on the national dna database laura richards a senior behavioural consultant with the mets racial and violent crime taskforce said officers often did not swab domestic abusers for dna because consent rather than identification was at issue and they were not considering the offender as a suspect for other crimes but she said it was vital for detectives to realise that men who beat up or raped wives or girlfriends were also good candidates for stranger rapes she pointed to a large number of murderers who had a history of physical sexual or psychological domestic abuse the soham killer ian huntley graham coutts who strangled brighton teacher jane longhurst barry george who shot jill dando and serial killer fred west there was also the recent case of m rapist antoni imiela who had previous convictions for burglary and assault who raped at least eight women and girls and was eventually caught through dna if youre violent in one context youre often violent in another said ms richards there is a definite link between domestic violence and stranger rape have the police really learned lessons from all these older cases such men she said were often serial perpetrators and skilled manipulators who went from one abusive relationship to another getting progressively more violent but also better at covering their tracks unfortunately the more contact perpetrators have with police and the criminal justice system the better they get at getting away with it she said although reporting of rape continues to rise by in convictions in england and wales are at a year low there are two domestic murders a week in england and wales and two a month in london accounting for a quarter of all homicides in the capital the met receive calls a year about domestic violence about one every six minutes in many cases there has been a long history of abuse before a murder is committed but domestic assault and rape cases are difficult to bring to court with victims unwilling to testify or worried their children will be taken away from them ms richards argued that for this reason a standalone register for domestic text: ministers are poised to jettison part of a plan to cut the number of bitter and protracted court battles between parents over child contact the department for constitutional affairs was to pilot early intervention this year under which separating parents would be presented with parenting plans from which to choose based on an idea that has reduced the number of court battles over children in the us the templates would give both divorced parents generous time with their children now the initiative has been taken over by the department for education and skills but its model under consideration is a more ad hoc scheme by which parents would be helped by mediation to work out their own plans those who favour the usstyle plans who include some judges say mediation has been tried already with little success mediation is voluntary and mothers determined to frustrate their expartners attempts to see their children are unlikely to cooperate the apparent change of plan is a severe blow to fathers groups which have resorted to increasingly desperate stunts up to of divorced fathers lose contact with their children altogether fathers who have dressed as action figures to scale bridges and buildings including the royal courts of justice in london have moved the issue up the agenda police have had to deal with traffic disruption and threats to public order while protesters who had dressed as batman robin superman and spiderman face criminal prosecution for climbing the clifton suspension bridge in bristol judges admit the system does not work with the court battles more than doubling in years prince charles was moved to comment on the issue this week the system seemed unfair to divorced fathers and weighted towards mothers he said during a discussion with servicemen while on an official visit to a naval welfare association the early intervention project drawn up by a group including officials and judges aimed to bring parents together from the point of separation and help them to reach agreement parents would be helped to deal with the anger left over from their relationship in an attempt to eliminate obstacles to cooperation they would be taught how to handle the problems of postdivorce parenting and be told of the psychological harm that parental battles or being deprived of one parent can do to children the group now responsible for the initiative met for the first time this week some involved in the discussions are said to be concerned that usstyle templates conflict with the principles of the children act which requires the courts to consider the best interests of the child hamish cameron a child psychiatrist who supports the initial plan said what you do is you present these parenting plans which are different sorts of weekly schedules and say you choose the one that suits you best if it doesnt work well modify it whereas if you start with a blank slate its hopeless you have oh he can have the child once a month or alternate saturdays youve got to have some kind of template of what the state considers reasonable the florida statute says that parents should have continuing and regular contact with their children and that includes text: the higher education sector could be plunged into crisis unless young women are given more encouragement to aim for top jobs in academia where their sex remain seriously underrepresented the head of the universities umbrella group warned last night in a hardhitting speech lady warwick said there were negative knockon effects for public life if higher education continued to be perceived as a maledominated culture with limited opportunities and challenges for women her analysis of the gender split showed that of the heads of higher education institutions which include universities as well as specialist colleges only are women while there are only women vicechancellors of universities of the total at professorial level women are particularly badly represented in senior jobs in science and engineering lady warwick said but even where they were better represented in softer subjects such as the arts and humanities their numbers still failed to reflect the huge proportion of woman studying these areas overall women tend to be involved in teaching and learning rather than research and are more involved in pastoral care than their male colleagues lady warwick who is the chief executive of universities uk was giving the barbara diamond memorial lecture held each year on the issue of women and equality to an audience of educationalists at the university of westminster in london she said despite many government initiatives since labours election victory of aimed at raising the profile of the equality and diversity agenda there was a long way to go in this changed environment standards and expectations of fairness and equality of opportunity have been raised she said academia cannot isolate itself from the real world and pursue learning exclusively it must legitimise itself by reflecting the society it serves the underrepresentation of women had enormous knockon effects for the rest of society the promotion of women is not just of importance to the higher education sector it has implications for the wider community when there is a small number of women in senior positions there is a small number of women who are qualified to join outside bodies this produces a spinoff effect which leads to unbalanced royal commissions representation on governing bodies of public service providers and so on the level of representation of women at the top level in higher education institutions was not atypical of the public sector she added but even in the civil service jobs in the equivalent of professorial level one down from permanent secretary were more within the reach for women even when women in highpowered jobs sat on senior committees they tended to be concerned with student welfare or teaching and learning these are not the bigexpenditure highprestige committees like planning and resources or research women do not then gain the experience of allocating and managing large budgets and of being involved in making the strategic decisions that would enable them to take the next step up within the institution family responsibilities were also an issue she said and while women should not have to choose between their careers and their families the long hours culture as well as the need to publish attend conferences to network both nationally and internationally make it very much more difficult for the person who bears the main burden of responsibilities at home the sector had to take steps to ensure it did not deter the women leaders of the future if we dont encourage these young women it may well leave us with a sector in crisis and unable to meet the needs of the increasing numbers of students expected to pass through the system in the coming years it isnt any good for us if higher education is perceived as being a maledominated culture we need diversity within the sector we need to encourage as much new blood and as many of the sharpest minds as we can and if these people are being turned off and going into industry and other sectors it will be damaging ultimately to the country as a whole

services has been estimated at more than bn a year and every year in england and wales around women and children spend at least one night in a refuge under the crime and disorder act the nhs was made post when it was created in ive also been a magistrate for years so i know something about how the legal system works nurses and other health professionals see women all the time and frontline staff need to have guidelines on how to deal with the problem as the biggest employer of women in britain some of those women in the nhs are going to be victims of domestic abuse themselves and we need to card with advice such as if you leave try to take some money for taxis try to take your medical card and passport that is the sort of practical advice that women need the average woman is not going to text: pregnancyrelated dismissals ought to be the most straightforward of sex discrimination cases but unfortunately they arent employment tribunals look at about cases of unfair dismissal on the grounds of pregnancy every year and this figure alone suggests the issue is far from simple only complex cases get as far as a tribunal proper if you include those which are settled before this point and the ones which are never brought because the potential applicant is too dispirited the problem becomes much bigger why should it be so unfair dismissals over pregnancy will usually show a much clearer line of cause and effect than other cases all is going well you get pregnant you tell your boss you are fired shortly afterwards the equal opportunities commission claims that employment tribunals are not as helpful to pregnant women as they could be the requirement that cases be brought within three months for example coincides with the time a pregnant woman will have other things on her mind than legal disputes the average compensation awarded for unfair dismissal is about of the average compensation paid in other types of case these facts together with the individual examples of brutal behaviour to pregnant women should make all mothers angry but employers have their grievances too the eoc in an ongoing survey of employers attitudes found a woman who runs a small business and felt intimidated by the law into keeping on an employee who took six months sick leave during her pregnancy a hard case but the eocs argument that since it costs an average to replace a worker it is more economical to retain a pregnant worker than sack her does not really stand up the costs to an employer of having an employee on maternity leave are not zero and it is doubtful whether the costs of replacing a young worker amount to but there is no magic sum which covers the cost of behaving decently it is just something we ought to do human nature keeps lawyers in business but a few more attempts to avoid sending them any more business might not go amiss

text: patricia hewitt the womens minister in cabinet yesterday warned that pressure was building across government and among labour mps to revert to what she describes as a form of latenight harddrinking yah boo politics that would leave the public even more disengaged from parliament such a move would be a disaster for the cause of public service reform the modernisation of parliament and working women ms hewitts comments come after one woman labour mp jane griffiths accused elements of her local party of sexism after it chose to remove her as its candidate at the next election at the weekend ms griffiths also claimed she had been sexually harassed at westminster speaking to the guardian ms hewitt admitted there was a serious groundswell of pressure across government to revert to the latenight parliamentary sittings hours with some claiming the recent disaffected mood among labour mps has been caused by the end to latenight sittings a review of the twoyearold experiment led by the commons modernisation committee is under way following a demand from mps from all parties especially older male labour mps in remarks that will infuriate some in the parliamentary labour party she said there are several of us that think going back to the th century working hours would be a disaster she added the sight of mps voting at oclock at night with mps often the worse for wear debating and voting only confirms parliament is in another world and it is not part of any normal world most people think you cannot make a decision late at night particulary after a good meal late night politics and the yah boo that goes with it puts off a lot of potential women candidates and the wider public they just think it is a life that they dont want to be part of she said politics will only reengage with society if parliament in terms of the number of women ethnic minorities and young people reflects modern society she attacked as disgraceful the recent decision of brent east constituency labour party to keep shahid malik a wellknown labour activist off the short list for the parliamentary nomination it sends out messages she said even though the local party had eventually selected an asian woman ms hewitt also disclosed that a survey of prospective parliamentary candidates conducted by the plp womens committee had shown what she described as real shock from many prospective parliamentary candidates at the idea of reverting to the old hours she said if having bitten on the bullet of reform we now retreat because it is uncomfortable and difficult for those that are used to the old ways then we undermine our whole case for public service reform she argued that mps would be condemned as hypocritical recalling the longer the firemens dispute went on the more we discovered what was going on with the working practices in the fire service firemen had clearly developed and built their lives round a pattern of working that enabled a lot of them to have second jobs for men as well as women the commons should be part of the normal world she said rather than a throwback to the th century when men who worked in the city and the law courts by day would run the country with a good bottle of wine in the evening she said reversion to the old hours would be a defeat for the advocates of a decent worklife balance we as a government introduced new laws a year ago to make it easier for parents to balance work and family if we bottle it now as a parliament we are sending a message to business and the whole economy she dismissed suggestions that the rebelliousness of mps had been fostered by the lack of opportunity for mps to socialise together and discuss politics ahead of latenight votes she said ministers had to listen to backbenchers more closely but she did not think labour mps could discuss politics only when they are corralled together for latenight votes

women in senior positions were more likely to have a drink problem than their male peers and were turning to the bottle far more often than less successful women jenny head from university college london who led the study said one possible reason might be that its the stress of working against a glass ceiling the study found that women in highly paid highly pressured jobs were three times more likely to be alcohol dependent than those in the lowestgrade jobs but mens vulnerability to drinking did not alter as they climbed up the career ladder the findings reported in the journal occupational and environmental medicine are based on questionnaire responses from about civil servants working in different departments in london twothirds of those taking part in the whitehall study conducted by the electoral commission the report gender and political participation destroys the myth that women are less likely to turn out to national regional or local elections than men pointing out that levels of turnout are statistically comparable and it points out that women are more likely to be involved in causeorientated activities such as signing a petition or boycotting products for ethical reasons but when it comes to involvement in campaignorientated activities such as contacting a politician donating money to or working for a political party women are significantly less likely to be involved according to the research by academics at harvard and birkbeck college london at the last election turnout among women voters was higher than among men where a woman mp was elected text: its a simple idea where everyone wins the high cost of childcare stops many unemployed parents from getting jobs or training so why not provide free childcare facilities while training those who want a career in childcare the east london childcare institute elci britains first dedicated childcare training centre was formally opened in stratford this month and aims to create around qualified childcare workers over the next five years there are about house holds in london in which no adult is working and so cannot afford to pay for childcare which in the capital costs up to more than in the rest of the country as a result parents are unable to take job and training opportunities and so remain in the unemployment and poverty trap chris leigh chief executive of newhambased newtech which runs elci says its a very straightforward solution to a complicated problem we try not to turn anyone away and can provide daytime evening and weekend courses from introductory national vocational qualifications up to foundation degree level students will be able to gain work experience in the centres own creche and we will also provide an agency offering locum cover so that fulltime staff from elsewhere can go on to further training and our students can gain valuable experience elci is aimed at unemployed or lowincome parents particularly those from newhams large asian community who are least likely to be able to afford childcare it will also provide careers advice for existing childcare workers and support for people wanting to set up a childcare business the scheme is funded by a m grant from the london development agency lda that included the cost of building the new centre plus m from the learning and skills council newham council and the european regional fund londons mayor ken livingstone says that if the scheme proves a success it could be replicated in other parts of the capital with lda and greater london authority funding the daycare trust a national childcare charity believes that if the government is serious about tackling unemployment in deprived areas then centres like the one in stratford should be incorporated in regeneration programmes across the country julies emmanuel is one of the first graduates of an eightweek pilot course run by elci in west ham on the gainsborough park estate where she lives taking her first granddaughter to school prompted her to think about the elci course and going into childminding as a career it was a bit like going back to school at first with all the paperwork and essays she says but now i am a registered childminder and i am also enrolled on an early years course she admits that initially it was a struggle coming off benefits and starting paid work and she needed transitionary help from social services to support her through the weeks of study when she was not working it was a slog at first but it was worth it because it has made me a happier person she says i now look after four kids every day and i have got out and met new families and made new friends more details of the east london childcare institute at wwwldagovuk newham training and education centre is at wwwnewtecacuk

text: in the past few weeks the european court of justice has made two decisions which safeguard the rights of mothers on maternity leave the nub of both decisions is that mothers should not have to forfeit benefits they would have otherwise enjoyed just because they were away from work one case was homegrown the court finally reached a conclusion regarding michelle alabaster v woolwich building society and the secretary of state for social security albeit belatedly as alabaster became pregnant in in september of that year her six weeks of statutory maternity pay was calculated at of her earnings in december she was awarded a pay rise she assumed that her maternity pay would go up too but the powers that be decided to keep to the letter of the law which says that maternity pay is fixed according to earnings in the fifth and sixth month of pregnancy the court eventually disagreed with this interpretation by comparison the case of merino gomez v continental industrias has raced through the courts gomez took her maternity leave from may to august during that time continental industrias closed for its fourweek summer holiday when she returned she assumed she still had her holiday entitlement no said her employer you werent here you missed out gomez objected and took the company to court where it was held that annual leave and mater nity leave are separate it was irrelevant that gomez was on leave during the firms holiday period as was the fact that continental industrias holiday arrangements were the result of a collective agreement she should not forfeit her right to annual leave through pregnancy any more than alabaster should have lost six weeks of her pay rise the courts judgment should be the precedent that employment tribunals and ideally employers will follow from now on there is a backlog of similar cases waiting to be resolved on the basis of the courts decision hopefully few have been waiting as long as alabaster

text: men who commit domestic violence may be suffering a form of panic attack that they direct against their partners according to one of britains most respected experts in the field of domestic abuse dr elizabeth gilchrist will launch a fiveyear million research project later this year to attempt to prove her initial research findings which indicate that acts of domestic violence are a defence response to undetected panic attacks i am very clear that there is no excuse for domestic violence said gilchrist a forensic psychologist at coventry university who has worked with domestic violence offenders for years this is about looking for effective ways of intervention to make women and children safer im aware that our findings could initially look controversial but the failure of current treatment programmes to stop perpetrators reoffending is evidence enough that we need to look at the issue with fresh eyes gilchrists findings have been criticised by campaigners against domestic violence who fear they will be used by offenders to absolve them of responsibility for their crime this is exactly the sort of dangerous claim that is used by both offenders and victims of abuse to shift responsibility for the crime away from the perpetrator said linda regan of the child and women abuse studies unit at london metropolitan university if this is true then why dont the perpetrators hit their bosses and friends as well why is it only their partners who get attacked recent research on jailed offenders in america has found that those committing domestic violence experience sensations immediately before and during an act of violence similar to those felt by people having panic attacks the research carried out by dr david george at the national institute on alcohol abuse and alcoholism also showed that the brain mechanisms of offenders that are activated during defensive aggression are similar to those triggered during a panic attack both gilchrist and the coauthor of her study dr ian mitchell a neuropsychologist at the university of birmingham believe offenders have one of two psychological profiles seventyfive per cent register as antisocial narcissists who attack women in order to exert power others are borderline dysphoric who abuse their partners in an unplanned spontaneous and reactive manner we need to have a full and frank discussion about domestic violence if we are ever going to have a chance of stopping it said gilchrist of course these men need to have a distorted view of women for a panic attack to result in physical aggression but that doesnt mean there isnt some further reason why their panic sparks such an extreme response the study which will focus on imprisoned offenders will first determine whether there is a subgroup of domestic violence perpetrators who are particularly susceptible to panic attacks if so gilchrist and mitchell will investigate whether there is a form of medical intervention that could suppress the likelihood of a panic attack triggering an aggressive reaction mitchell warns however that any treatment will be difficult to administer because panic responses are notoriously difficult to suppress and because over time they become more extreme so any treatment would need to be continually adjusted

text: negotiating a pay rise or business deal with a member of the opposite sex produces the best results according to research presented at the royal economic societys annual conference yesterday women negotiate better with a man and vice versa and men and women be come overcompetitive when dealing with someone of the same sex the research found experimental evidence of the importance of gender pairing in bargaining was presented at the university of wales swansea researchers said their evidence may be of interest to certain institutions wanting to select strategically the gender of their representatives the research was conducted by a team from austria germany and the netherlands four economists matthias sutter ronald bosman martin kocher and frans van winden found evidence that gender pairing matters a lot they found a mixed pairing a man and a woman fosters significantly more cooperation in a business or professional setting mixed gender pairing leads to less competitive bargaining and less retaliation and favours mutually beneficial deals but same gender pairing two men or two women leads to more competitive behaviour and a higher probability that scarce resources will be wasted the research found the findings are based on laboratory experiments using a bargaining game resembling a range of economic situations the conference is taking place from april to

text: divorcing parents will be diverted from court and helped to resolve their own child contact disputes with generous parenting time for both under a radical overhaul of the failing family justice system a green paper in june or july will outline proposals for parents to be taught how to put aside their own anger focus on the childrens best interests and negotiate a postseparation parenting plan a national helpline open day and night could help parents needing advice on how to make contact work the announcement comes a day after a high court family division judge mr justice munby delivered a blistering attack on the system which saw a father leave his court in tears after being driven to end a fiveyear battle to see his daughter which had involved court hearings lord filkin the family justice minister in the department of constitutional affairs yesterday promised a green paper before parliaments summer recess would set out a better system pilot projects in london brighton and sunderland to try out early intervention in contact disputes before they reach court are now expected to require parents to go to mediation instead of the original proposal to encourage mediation unveiled this month fathers groups had predicted that they would be doomed to failure because mothers who were determined to deny fathers contact would not agree to mediate lord filkin said the governments starting point was that children did not want to be involved in the middle of some ghastly fight adding we also are pretty clear that courts are not the best places to get people to change their behaviour although contact time would vary depending on the circumstances there would be clear expectations that both parents would have the time to form a meaningful relationship with the child that could mean agreeing usstyle parenting plans setting out weekly access we would be looking at a range of ways of trying to help parents shift their behaviour focus on the interests of the child get an understanding of how to go about negotiating with their former partner he said the term parenting classes was a turnoff he added but parental education of some kind was necessary lord text: radical proposals to extend statutory paid maternity leave by a further six months and earmark a portion for fathers only under a socalled daddy leave scheme could feature in labours election manifesto for a third term in government it emerged last night the plan was floated in a speech by the childrens minister margaret hodge who said it would give working parents the chance to spend the crucial first year of their new babys life at home while recognising the important role of fathers who even with limited paid leave rarely take time off at this stage it is one of a series of initiatives being considered for inclusion in labours general election manifesto in a keynote speech to the social market foundation in london last night mrs hodge said labours determination to further improve early years and childcare services and develop more familyfriendly policies was driven by its belief in gender equality there was much talk about the rights of parents but not enough done to support both parents to exercise their rights and fulfil their responsibilities to their children mrs hodge said in my view we should be working towards parents having the opportunity to stay at home for the crucial first year of their childs life and that opportunity should be open to both fathers and mothers she added all the research confirms the important role fathers as well as mothers play in their childrens lives yet too few fathers take time out of work in the first year of their childs life to care for their baby this is partly a result of pay differences between men and women partly a result of social norms and expectations mrs hodge who has recently returned from sweden where fathers receive more generous paid leave than in the uk said any extension to existing benefits would need to be affordable but one possibility could be to extend paid maternity leave for a further six months however we should not naturally assume that this role falls on the mother alone parents themselves not government are best placed to decide who should stay at home and care for their own child employers should be working closely with government to develop more opportunities for fathers to take time to care for very young children she said for example measures such as reserving a portion of leave that could only be taken by fathers daddy leave may be one way to encourage fathers to spend more time at home last april the government introduced familyfriendly policies that included giving parents with children under the age of six the right to ask bosses to consider flexible working arrangements an increase in statutory maternity pay to a maximum of a week and an increase in paid maternity leave by eight weeks to weeks which with the prospect of a further six months of unpaid leave could give many mothers a year off for the first time new fathers were given the right to two weeks paid paternity leave at a week the tuc general secretary brendan barber welcomed the idea of increased leave but said for the extended leave to make a real difference to all parents it would have to be paid otherwise only the more affluent mums and dads would be able to reap the benefits it was also welcomed by julie mellor who chairs the equal opportunities commission financial pressures mean that many parents return to work before they are ready she said but susan anderson human resources director at the confederation of british industry said these flexible working rights are only one year old and companies would be extremely concerned to learn that the government is considering extension at this early stage this could jeopardise the good progress that has been made

text: jenny mccartney sunday telegraph may members of fathers justice the directaction fathers rights group flourbombed the chamber of the house of commons last week as they bask in the flurry of publicity they probably dont care that it is largely publicity of the wrong sort this is especially sad because so much of what fathers justice says is perfectly sensible there are indeed many fathers who have suffered appalling injustices in the toxic quagmire of divorce and who rightly feel that the legal system is stacked against them although many divorcing couples manage to negotiate joint access to their children fairly many do not it thus falls to the courts to make contact orders but if the resident parent who is usually the mother should fail to uphold it it is rarely enforced any further deborah orr the independent may an obsession with their own plight rather than the pursuit of a more inclusive approach makes fathers justice an unattractive organisation there is wide public sympathy for the plight of fathers who are maliciously denied access to their children but there is also an uncomfortable recognition that if a former couple are so unable to decide between themselves what is best for their children then the courts have little prospect of doing it for them jailing mothers who defy court orders or fining them punishes the child as well as the mother the only hope of men in such a ghastly situation is that they can somehow repair the rift in the parental relationship by deciding to take such a decisive step into the public arena and to orchestrate such a highprofile mediafriendly campaign fathers justice have opted instead for more confrontation their protests are provocative personal immature and egotistical people understand them to be the deeds of desperate people david aaronovitch the observer may the issue is so raw partly because of the coming together of two related trends the first is a sensitivity to the way in which women have been treated historically and the other is the changing view of fatherhood itself with many more men seeing themselves as cocarers than before it is very hard for the law to take account of both and this is where the fathers movement has a big problem there are not going to be jailings and finings of mums even if judges would do it most fathers wont pursue it the longterm answer has to lie in convincing more people to behave better in convincing them that it is shabby and damaging behaviour no matter how bitter they feel to exclude loving fathers from their childrens lives ferdinand mount sunday times may during the past years all our social arrangements not just the divorce laws but the tax and benefit systems too have been tilted away from preserving marriage to securing the rights of the individual in this atmosphere it is only to be expected that so many mothers should feel little obligation to share their children with their feckless and despicable exes it is not a question of rebalancing the scales in favour of men against women it is a question of loading the scales in favour of marriage and the stability that marriage alone with all its tribulations brings to society the deliberate demolition of all the structures supporting marriage has already caused more human misery in this country than any ricin or anthrax attack is likely to inflict on us yet it remains as hard as ever to persuade the politicians to pay much attention daily telegraph leader saturday may the angry fathers have a point but not much of a cause some men are indeed treated badly and many divorced men now expect to play a part in nurturing their children and that requires access on the other hand only in about one in cases do the courts bar fathers from any access many divorced fathers lose interest in children from a previous marriage and vigorously evade paying maintenance most judges keep their attention focused where it belongs on the welfare of the children fathers justice do not deserve a place in history alongside the suffragettes apart from anything else they do not seem very bright it has not occurred to them that their escapades only reinforce the stereotype of the irresponsible male janice turner the times may fathers justices demand that mothers and fathers are granted automatic equal access to children in divorce has never seemed more logical if women insist that we are entitled to half the marital chattels we must concede half our parenting rights we cannot demand that new dad takes his turn at the changing mat and the am feed then tell him should the relationship sour that he is only needed alternate weekends the last great movement of liberation after racial equality gay rights and feminism is surely masculine emancipation it can either take the form of marginalised malignant masculinity such as fathers justice or it can be supported by women who have everything to gain from happier men

text: ministers this week said thousands of parents employing nannies would benefit from tax breaks that would end years of discrimination in favour of those who use childminders and nurseries minister for children margaret hodge said many parents would welcome the reforms which are due to take effect from april next year she expected the move will create jobs for carers but proposals outlining the tax break first announced in the budget drew fire from accountants who said plans for a ceiling on joint salaries of would rule out most parents who used nannies and turn the scheme into a publicity stunt mike warburton of accountant grant thornton said few couples who earned could afford a nanny in the first place and the limited tax credit on offer would fail to make employing a nanny more attractive it is only worth employing a nanny if both parents are working if one parent earns and another they are immediately over the threshold i think parents need a joint income more like to before it becomes viable to employ a nanny a sliding scale from to will also leave higher earning families with a few crumbs the professional association of nursery nurses which represents many of the estimated to nannies working in britain says initially the impact will be small however takeup could grow quickly spokeswoman tricia pritchard says the people i see benefiting are single parents who will not have looked at employing a nanny before they will often need the flexible childcare a nanny offers and earn less than she says there is growing use of parttime nannies which may become more affordable among middle income groups mr warburton argues that whatever happens the scheme will like most of the governments tax credits be tricky to understand and claim so below we clarify the details and look at who will and who will not benefit whats on offer there are no new state benefit or tax credit up for grabs families can get financial support under the existing childcare element of the working tax credit and employersupported childcare schemes the tax credit can only be paid to parents using eligible childcare the government is proposing to expand this range of childcare by setting up a fasttrack voluntary scheme under which childcarers like nannies can be approved for financial support to get approval they must either have a recognised childcare qualification or attend a childcare induction course have their criminal records checked and hold a valid first aid certificate relevant to the care of children which types of childcare will get approval carers who look after children in your home such as nannies and friends individuals providing a childminding service in their own home for children over the age of seven breakfast holiday and activity clubs for children over the age of seven where the main purpose is to provide childcare services run by schools are already eligible for tax credits clubs and activities for children under eight that are of less than two hours duration per day is any type of childcare excluded from this new approval scheme yes residential holiday providers where you pack your children off for a week of fun will not be eligible most important for the many people who rely on grandparents aunts and other relatives is that care provided by an individual in the parents home will not be eligible for tax credits if the carer is related to the child the government says it does not think it appropriate to intervene in private family arrangements however there has always been the option for grandparents and other relatives to register as childminders and look after children in their own the carers home this does of course involve more extensive checks including inspection of the carers home to see that it meets certain standards but a registered childminder whether or not they are related to the children they care for will be eligible for financial support so supposing my nanny gets approval under the new scheme remind me how i qualify for the childcare tax credit this is a benefit an element within the working tax credit available to families with one child earning up to a year or those with two chil dren or more earning up to a year likely to be uprated next year when the rule takes effect who pay for some form of eligible childcare single parents or both parents in a couple must be working at least hours a week to qualify and how much is the tax credit worth it pays up to per cent of your childcare costs the percentage you get depends on your income subject to maximum limits on the weekly costs you can claim for if you pay for care for one child the weekly limit on costs is so the maximum you can receive at is a week if you pay for care for two or more children the weekly limit is and therefore the maximum claim is the national childcare charity daycare trust is campaigning for more help with childcare costs through the tax credit for working families particularly those on lower incomes who it points out still have to find at least a hefty per cent of the cost of childcare how does the new approval scheme affect employersupported childcare at present employees can use employerprovided childcare vouchers to fund childcare from any provider whether registered or not and the full cost of the voucher is exempt from national insurance contributions nics so an employee using childcare vouchers to pay for unregistered care can save up to per cent nics from april as announced in the budget employees will be able to get the first a week of employerprovided childcare vouchers free of income tax as well as nics but the exemption will only apply from april if they use registered childcare or childcare approved under the new scheme what if i use registered or approved childcare while qualifying for the tax credit and my employer also offers me childcare vouchers can i benefit from both types of support towards my childcare costs the inland revenue says whatever amount is covered by the employer does not count towards a claim for the childcare element it means the childcare element covers up to per cent of the costs left over after employer contributions a spokeswoman said for example if the costs are before any kind of support and the employer was providing of vouchers to go towards the costs the family would get the childcare element of up to of the remaining they would also get the tax and nics exemption on the voucher from the employer the daycare trust says the tradeoff between the voucher from an employer and the childcare element should force parents to look at how much they might get through the tax credit before they consider whether to take up childcare vouchers you can get advice on tax credits and claim forms from text: their slogan is the title of a manic street preachers song if you tolerate this then your children will be next their membership is flourishing and their tactics are increasingly militant in the months since fathers justice was formed by matt oconnor a marketing consultant the issue of a fathers right to see his child has been highlighted as never before but the campaign group has become increasingly confrontationalsolicitors have been bombarded with abusive emails court offices stormed and judges visited at their homes leading to accusations from lawyers and exwives that the organisation has created an atmosphere of intimidation and fear while prominent members of the group defend these tactics the truth behind many of the cases they publicise is more complex than their slogans suggest former wives and girlfriends who spoke to the guardian described relationship break ups involving domestic violence being forced to live in refuges and incidents in which their children witnessed frightening aggression by their fathers mr oconnors exwife sophie a primary school teacher who is now on good terms with her former husband said there is always a story behind every case every case is individual women have their own reasons for what they do sometimes they have good reasons in ms oconnors opinion the role of the law is to protect the woman and children when a relationship breaks down fathers justice suggest women should go to prison if they dont keep to the contact orders that is just not going to happen like it or not women are the primary carers i know that is not the popular view but it is generally true the case of conrad campbell is an example of the allegations and counter allegations bitterness and anger which engulf relationship breakdowns and defy easy solutions mr campbell joined fathers justice out of desperation after losing contact with his child i went to prison for days last summer just for texting my son because it was his birthday that week he said she the childs mother said i was in breach of an injunction because i was trying to keep up contact with my son that it was harassment and she was in fear of her life and i was sent to jail he does however admit assaulting his partner and being sent on a programme to tackle his anger his expartner who did not wish to be named says she was the victim of a domestic assault by her childs father but despite this he was allowed contact with the boy after their break up he gave up his parental responsibility she said this is what i cannot understand he had access he used to see him in a care centre then one time we arranged to meet and he tried to drag my son out of the car and smashed the door now he has got no access at all he is not allowed it flour bomb of all the demonstrations fathers justice has carried out from cranetop protests to the storming of court rooms none has created more publicity than last wednesdays flour bombing of the prime minister in the house of commons the men involved in these protests say on their website they try to adopt tactics which will make their children go wow thats my dad in reality the highprofile protests embarrass children and often frighten their mothers i wasnt surprised when i saw the house of commons thing said ms oconnor matthew is a very active campaigner and his aim is to get publicity but i think all children tend to be embarrassed by their parents and mine are at the age that they cringe when he gets on the television another exwife described the tactics as very childish they dont take anyone elses thoughts into consideration so how can they expect us to believe they are doing this because they are thinking of their children they act like boys who get angry and frustrated when they cant because they are being awkward sometimes because of their partners being awkward said one family lawyer but these men do not help themselves by joining this sort of paranoid organisation which adopts aggressive intimidating tactics people who deal with women who have suffered violence at the hands of their partners believe the activities of fathers justice obscure the truth about fathers rights the whole thing is a bit of a myth said sandra horley the chief executive of refuge figures last year showed the courts dealt with around cases and men were refused contact in cases thats about so i think they have exaggerated this out of all proportion mr oconnor says the failure of the courts to uphold a mans right to see his child has caused membership to boom to in the past year and he promises more radical protests in the future

text: at last there is to be a tax break for nannyemploying working parents this week the government announced that from april families using nannies to care for their kids would be able to join those using nurseries and childminders in getting some cash back from the treasury to help them meet their costs but hold the rejoicing because theres more to this than meets the eye to start with its only families on a joint annual income of less than if they have one child or if they have two or more who qualify those arent tiny incomes but if you can afford a nanny at least in london or another big city it tends to mean you are a family with a higher joint income than that whats more to be eligible for the tax credit you need to register your nanny and have her policechecked on a register that incidentally doesnt yet exist whitehall is working on it for some families there is also the fact that they hire their nanny illegally without paying her tax or national insurance contributions registering her for the tax creditobviously also brings to the treasurys attention that she is an earner and therefore should be a taxpayer since paying her tax bill is your job as her employer the result to you is probably more burden than gain you benefit to the tune of the tax relief a week for one child or for two or more but you lose in terms of the tax and national insurance you are now required to pay on her behalf inevitably no one really knows what proportion of britains nannies are employed through informal cashinhand arrangements although anecdotally it would certainly seem to be huge it also raises the question of who exactly are todays nannies who are the women and very occasionally men in whose charge we leave our precious little bundles while we hurry off to the office the big divide in nannying is between the qualified and the unqualified but it doesnt follow that the unqualified are the less soughtafter parents on the whole tend to be more concerned with qualifications than they were in the past says annie prior who has run annies nannies in london for years but this is a business where you have to go with your instinct about who seems the right carer for your child speaking personally i had an unqualified nanny for years and she was wonderful having a rapport with children is crucial however qualified a nanny is if she doesnt seem to hit it off with the kids shes not going to get the job one of the big changes in the nannying landscape over the past couple of years says prior is the decline of superwoman the highearning flatout attheofficetillallhours mum has reassessed her life asked what its all for and is now favouring a more laidback two or three days a week working schedule for which she no longer needs fulltime nanny cover enter the niche nanny the new trend is for the nanny who is available exactly when you need her for just the hours you need her and who is paid accordingly foremost among the niche nannies are the new afterschool nannies who bridge the gap between the pm school bell and the pm office clockingoff time once your kids hit school age youre looking for a different kind of nanny and youre looking for different hours of cover says caroline cooke who set up the after school nannies agency two years ago parents dont want to be paying a nanny to sit around at home all day while their children are out when what they really need is someone to collect them from school make their tea and oversee their homework between pm and pm when i tried to find that kind of care i found it wasnt available so i set up the agency most of the nannies who work for me are nursery school teachers whove got time at the end of their working day to care for other peoples children for a few hours and are eminently wellqualified to do so night nannies is another niche agency for a night in london cheaper elsewhere they will provide you with a nanny to soothe feed quieten and even sleeptrain your baby so that you get an undisturbed kip people tend to use us in the early months for two or three nights a week it helps them get through that tiredness of being woken night after night says anastasia baker who set up night nannies four years ago the other sort of business we get is from parents with older babies who have got into bad habits and need some sleep training three nights usually does the trick ive got around nannies working across london most nights talk to nannies and what you pick up is that the muchhyped perks the car the flat the holiday in the caribbean the healthclub membership are not what count ultimately what every nanny wants is to find a family they gel with and feel part of and who respect their work says caroline burke who has nannied for years in my experience most nannies prefer to live out whatever the cost and however exciting the inhouse perks because if theyre inhouse its hard not to get involved when youre off duty and you want your own life most of us dont like nanny shares because theyre complicated and you tend to find one family resenting the time youre spending with the other one the main bugbears tend to be the employers who are supposed to be home at pm but who roll home at pm and dont seem to realise why youre put out and the ones who talk down to you and dont treat you with respect but says burke the biggest problem for nannies is the lack of a career path you do your training youre good at your job but theres no promotion no career ladder you can go from one family to another but ultimately its the same job ive enjoyed it but ive recently decided to move on and im in the process of setting up a coffee shop for the eastern european au pairs the difficulties are more deeply felt some of us work hard for very little money in uk terms says yearold marika who trained as a teacher in her native slovakia ive been paid a week as an au pair now though ive moved out and i do two different nannying jobs that together bring in a week its a fortune when you bear in mind that id be paid around a month if i went home and got a job as a teacher marika is happy with her lot but not all her friends are as lucky before you arrive youre told youll be doing five hours work a day five days a week but when you get here you realise they want you to do a lot more than that says anna and some people just arent welcomed into the family as au pairs should be i know one girl who has never in a year of living with them been invited to eat with the family you feel like you arent really cared for and youre a long way from your home and your own family meanwhile at playgroups baby gyms and one oclock clubs across the land there is a clear hierarchy in place as parents and nannies gather to watch the youngsters in their care mothers can spot nannies a mile off and nannies can spot mothers a mile off says burke sometimes mothers will talk to you and be pleasant but often theres a barrier you feel youre a bit of a nonperson with a mum someone she isnt going to waste her time talking to meanwhile english nannies tend to look down on the eastern european au pairs and badmouth their efforts to look after their charges you cant believe that sensible people would leave their babies with girls who hardly speak a word of english and wouldnt know how to dial in an emergency says one the au pairs for their part feel excluded the mothers talk to the mothers the english nannies talk to the english nannies and the slovakians talk to the slovakians says marika id hate to find i was the only au pair at a playgroup because no one would talk to me theyd say its because my english isnt good but perhaps my english would be better if they did speak to me a brief guide to the nanny state the norland nanny graduates of norland training colleges are the cream of british nannies most follow a twoyear course and though entry can be after gcse an increasing number are postalevel college fees are high a term and while bursaries are available many students are selffinancing which adds to the suspicion that some couples insist on a norlander so that shell be a gal with a bit of breeding snobbery apart the norland course is very thorough and there are always more vacancies than the inhouse jobs agency has norlanders to fill their nannies command salaries of up to net a week for jobs overseas net a week for livein jobs in london and a week for liveout jobs in the capital the australian new zealander or south african mothers help if youre not in the norland bracket an au pair or mothers help from the above countries could be your preference much more affordable expect to pay in the region of for a liveout in the southeast perhaps or if shes living in some newworld nannies have qualifications most have experience of looking after other peoples kids but what theyre renowned for is their ability to muck in and be jolly on the down side theyre often too ready to move on the treasure in her s or s the treasure has raised her own kids and if she has grandchildren is likely to be involved in looking after them as well what she lacks in professional qualifications she more than makes up for in experience with a treasure it is less what you tell her and more how you watch her to pick up tips more affordable than norlanders around a week net treasures also tend to move around less often than younger nannies on the down side theyre always ripe for poachers so you have to keep them sweet the homegrown nneb collegetrained nnebs arent as sought after as is sometimes believed after a spate of news stories about how their incomes were climbing higher and higher some reportedly earn more than a year in central london agencies reported a decline in demand fuelled partly by mothers wanting to work parttime and nnebs holding out for fulltime jobs couples looked elsewhere for flexible childcare hence the rise of the newworld nanny the eastern european au pair in the nappy valley of the eastern european nanny is ubiquitous mostly young women and occasionally young men they are often in their early s and postuniversity and ridiculously cheap less than a week in london for five hours childcare a day plus board and lodging but they are getting more savvy especially now that their countries have joined the eu they are moving out of family homes into their own flats and rented rooms and demanding higher payments of and an hour

text: they gave their names to our nanny culture helped to raise hundreds of thousands of youngsters and were celebrated by julie andrews in mary poppins now nannies are to become the subject of tax breaks ministers will reveal tomorrow that parents who hire people to look after their children will be eligible for tax relief in this way mothers will be encouraged to go back to work at present many families are being priced out of childcare by crippling costs a fulltime nanny in london can earn up to a year more than a womans average salary the perk is not restricted to fulltime nannies it will also be extended to those who use afterschool and holiday clubs or who employ trained childminders in the childs own home but relatives who look after children in their own homes will be excluded michael howards private polling is understood to show that while he is picking up support among men he is not making inroads among women and aides are anxious to find something to say to female voters text: welcome to the wrap guardian unlimiteds roundup of the best of the days papers also in todays wrap blair urged to distance himself from white house mirror photos row continues and trouble and strife at portsmouth fc papers hail gandhi election triumph the rise of sonia gandhi and fall of indias ruling bhatratiya janata party bjp are celebrated by most of the papers this morning the italianborn leader of the congress party who is the widow of former premier rajiv gandhi is on the brink of taking power in the worlds largest democracy having pulled off a surprise victory over the hindu nationalist bjp the result heralds an extraordinary political rebirth for a leader and a party that have been written off on numerous occasions even in recent weeks says the financial times most commentators though it impossible that a foreignborn woman leader who was previously a housewife could become prime minister the commentators werent alone the bjp did not expect to lose campaigning under the slogan india shining the party was certain that the countrys strong economy and the prospect of peace with pakistan would carry it back into office the broadsheets make much of mrs gandhis amazing life story perhaps the best is randeep rameshs risotto to raj saga in the guardian for sonia it is in the small town of orbassano seven miles from italys busy metropolis of turin that her extraordinary journey begins he writes arriving in india in the young mrs gandhi struggled to cope with the countrys deeply ingrained culture at first she did not like indian food or clothes and there was a minor uproar when she was pictured in a miniskirt sucking on a lolly its top stuff ramesh also writes fascinatingly about the reasons for mrs gandhis triumph which he attributes to the magnetic power of her family name and her strategy of targeting rural india which remains chained to poverty and left behind as the urban centres modernise her message that india did not shine outside of its conurbations was successful because it was true he says bronwen maddox in the times disagrees for her the results cannot simply be explained by a rural bitterness at the evolution of two indias instead she believes that the rural backlash appears to have been part of a wider antiincumbent sentiment which indian voters have repeatedly turned on their leaders she does however agree with the guardians leader which cheers a vote against nationalism and sectarianism that the return to life of the congress party is reassuring because it bolsters the secular foundations of indias democracy which had seemed under threat during the bjps rule gandhi dynasty rises again the dynasty continues ft indian electorate throws out vajpayee pm urged to distance himself from bush the guardian text: when the electoral commission discovered last month that women dont involve themselves in party politics preferring to vote sign petitions and talk behind the scenes worried female columnists in westminster came up with a variety of explanations women dont like joining groups they dont like swallowing a party manifesto whole they think there are too many men in the game and too few women these are plausible enough explanations but the one that caught my eye turned up a few paragraphs down the reports noted slightly shamefacedly women have relatively little confidence in their ability to influence the political process never mind the guff about women preferring to vote for women this is the key finding unfortunately theres no easy fix for a lack of selfbelief even more depressingly womens reticence is evident in the bright new playground which the fringes of westminster are beginning to notice that of political blogs women do blog according to a blogcensus survey last august just under of englishlanguage weblogs were owned by men and by women the rest belonged to groups or were of unknown origin but blogcensus also found that nearly half the weblogs surveyed were personal diaries and in that category women outnumbered men by about two to one fewer than one in of the political blogs was written by a woman disproportionate numbers of men are blogging about politics and technology says jane perrone the editor of the guardians weblog the uneven gender split is matched in the offline world that tallies with the latest sitemeter blog popularity rankings in the us of the top only one the satirical washington blog wonkette is written by a woman maledominated networks and inflexible working hours have traditionally hindered the progress of female politicians neither affects womens ability to join in the political blogging community yet very few do in january guardian unlimited politics invited readers to nominate their favourite political blogs and vote for a shortlist of all the blogs proposed only two were written by women lynne featherstones gla and haringey diary and the illinoisbased karmalised i personally hate making statements about women versus men says wonkette ana marie cox when i ask her why females are so underrepresented in the field gender essentialism is bad i will make some grand assumptions and hope that you understand female political bloggers that get linked to tend to write in a more frankly personal way sometimes even a flirtatious way i dont know if all women bloggers do many of the prominent female bloggers in the us she adds are rightwing what we call war bloggers women who first started to write after september a number make a point of supporting us soldiers abroad and consider their blogging a fundamentally patriotic moraleboosting exercise that particular impulse characteristic of us politics was briefly mirrored by democrats who built blogs to support the shortlived candidacy of howard dean cox herself admits she has been criticised by other female bloggers for talking like a sailor on wonkette whose running jokes about the size of john kerrys manhood and george bushs camper bodily postures sit alongside searing attacks on each mans political conduct yet she says if you look carefully i dont actually write about sex people think that im writing about myself but if anyone tried to find out about me theyd have a difficult job clues to the wonkette persona lie in the sketch at the top of the blog it shows a feisty young woman in boots and spectacles stretched out on a desk next to a cat theres a little stars and stripes tucked into her pencil mug think maggie gyllenhaal in secretary crossed with martha gellhorn and then add a pinch of irony cox points out that many of the more popular political bloggers are established journalists i mean ive been a journalist for ten years and its worth noting that most journalists are very good at hiding behind their copy revealing just enough to intrigue the reader making their point and dashing offstage without taking questions true some british female columnists have become a great deal more forthcoming about their private lives over the past decade many however have not take melanie phillips the daily mail columnist and blogger phillips does forceful detached outrage as well as any man and her private life is most definitely offlimits while you dont have to be madame de pompadour to win over the rest of the blogging community an element of titillation certainly appears to help and if as the electoral commission says women remain firmly outside the political establishment then provocation may be the best device for getting westminster and washingtons attention the good news is that women are starting to use weblogs as leverage to increase their influence says perrone i think things will change agrees cox and many male mps might well agree who wants to be sitting meekly in the commons chamber when you can be the star of the tearoom

text: occupational segregation by sex is an enduring aspect of the uk labour market according to a new study by the equal opportunities commission eoc out this week building and construction engineering and plumbing remain male bastions despite making desperate calls for female recruits to boost the number of entrants the eoc says its yearlong investigation concludes that recruiting more women in nontraditional occupations is the key to ending severe shortages of skilled workers in some parts of the labour market but many industries have failed to make any headway the report plugging britains skills gap challenging gender segregation in training and work identifies key barriers to women entering nontraditional occupations julie mellor chair of the eoc says skills shortages also have a significant impact on employers even highprofile projects such as heathrows terminal are having problems finding enough skilled workers in the short term the governments relaunch of the modern apprenticeship programme will provide an exciting opportunity to open up more choices for young people and supply business with a more diverse pool of workers the labour force statistics show that three quarters of working women are still found in just five occupational groups associate professional and technical such as nursing admin and secretarial work personal services such as caring for children or older people sales and customer service and nonskilled manual work the eoc figures indicate that in engineering women form of those taking modern apprenticeships and represent just of the engineering workforce in construction of people taking apprenticeships are women and women made up only of those working in construction jobs the eoc is calling on the government to respond to the report by developing a national strategy to tackle gender segregation in training and work this should incorporate targets to make change happen and provide incentives and information for young people and employers in skill shortage areas to make it easier for them to make nontraditional choices sir michael latham chairman of constructionskills says we welcome the equal opportunities commissions investigation into the gender gaps in industry only by tackling the shortage of women and ethnic minorities in the construction industry will we be able to address the industrys skills shortages the tendency for women to predomi nate in some occupations and men in others correlates with the subject choices made by boys and girls while still at school research shows that choices made at age are influenced by gender and are exactly mirrored in later choices of modern apprenticeships as background to the eoc investigation adults were questioned last month about their attitudes towards stereotypes of womens and mens working roles the survey showed that around half of women and men thought the advice they received on leaving school and deciding what kind of job they wanted to do was influenced by their gender copies of the eoc study plugging britains skills gap challenging gender segregation in training and work are available from its helpline and the full report is posted on its website eocorguk

text: recruiting more women into stereotypically male occupations such as construction is the answer to the uks severe shortage of skilled plumbers builders and engineers according to a new report an investigation by the equal opportunities commission published yesterday finds a clear link between shortage sectors well known to householders casting around for help when roofs leak or pipes burst and the under representation of women the eocs inquiry the first phase of a major investigation into gender segregation in work and training reveals that women are underrepresented in key areas including construction where they make up just of the workforce while the gender gap has closed to virtual parity in highstatus professional sectors such as law accountancy and medicine the numbers of women going into building plumbing engineering and information technology has barely altered in the last years the study shows meanwhile men are barely represented in childcare another fast expanding sector with a shortage of recruits far from improving the situation may be worsening since gender segregation on the governments modern apprenticeship scheme for young people is even more severe than in the workforce as a whole the eoc chairwoman julie mellor said yesterday that the research had identified real barriers to women joining certain occupations the situation not only perpetuated stereotypes but blighted individual businesses and hit the uks productivity occupational segregation also helps maintain britains pay gap where women in fulltime work are paid on average less an hour than men the report concludes recruiting more women is a clear solution to severe shortages of skilled workers in some parts of the labour market it also found that while a range of initiatives by employers and the government exists to increase the number of men or women in different jobs they are ineffective because there is no overall strategy and no local or national government targets lying behind the lack of women in traditionally male occupations is a range of factors from inadequate careers advice to prejudice or caution on the part of employers and the macho culture of some maledominated workplaces according to the study girls making careers choices are also unlikely to understand the pay advantages of conventionally male jobs the gap is glaring even at apprentice level according to figures in one region in modern apprentices in heating ventilation all male were paid an hour while those training in childcare all female earned an hour the government needs to go further than its current plans for restructuring modern apprenticeships to be unveiled by the chancellor gordon brown on monday the report says it also adds that companies should be offered a subsidy in order to help attract women into nontraditional jobs pat mcmullan national strategy manager for the gas company centrica said one young female wouldbe plumber had struggled to be accepted on to a training course and even to get past female receptionists when telephoning companies to ask about a career
