text: the village nursery is cheerful and calm the decor has been chosen by parents and children the coathooks were selected by thomas four because he says he likes bright blue opened six months ago the place nursery is housed in a strikingly imaginative purposebuilt childrens centre part of a sure start scheme in the grounds of george spurgeon school in one of the less affluent areas of folkestone kent democracy embraces more than the colour scheme what marks this place out is that it is a cooperative mutual society owned and run by the local community michelle rumsey a yearold mother of three is chair of the elected board that oversees the centre she also works parttime as a parent involvement worker ensuring regular contact with every parent in a community that includes more than families some of whom lead lives made chaotic by low incomes and a drug culture parent involvement means exactly that she says we dont just have a couple of token parents who are asked to say yes to everything we genuinely have parents involved in all the decisionmaking at every level and we constantly monitor and evaluate so that we know that the decisions that we are taking are working and supported by the majority cooperative childcare services have long been common in new zealand canada and sweden for parents concerned not just about standards but the values and ethos of the nursery in which their child is being raised it has obvious attractions childcare is an expanding industry but the dangers in relying on the private market have already been exposed while there are excellent exceptions profitmaking and the needs of shareholders often conflict with childrens wellbeing so in the uk its easy to find poorly paid unqualified and demoralised staff showing little interest in what they do so is it really any different at the village the straight answer is yes parents have set charges at an hour fees are subsidised by sure start with the involvement of kent county council shepway district council and the local primary care trust they reflect low incomes average annual salary in the area is and the proportion of parents on benefits factors that are unlikely to attract a private nursery developer to the area basic wages in the nursery however are at least above the minimum in addition all but one of the staff are qualified and all are highly motivated not least because they have a voice in the way in which the nursery is run further training is always on offer profits are ploughed back and the village is growing its own childcare staff parents are taking an nvq in childcare which involves them working in the nursery for several hours a week theresa hughes for example has three children aged eight and four the youngest has just transferred from the nursery to school theresa left school without qualifications but is now taking an nvq at the village she attends a lecture every fortnight and works three afternoons a week with the children it has made me think about how ive brought my own children up she says toni bonnett is the nursery manager she welcomes the constant discussions with parents over the principles of nursery practice professionally this is everything i believe in if parents are involved then standards are raised best practice is established and that really helps to change the profile of childcare for the benefit of the children the belief of the village is that when children transfer to school and a class of what counts most is their confidence and social skills if they lack selfesteem theyll be lost among so many and they wont have the ability to learn bonnett says cooperatives arent easy to establish or sustain in folkestone the challenge was acute deprivation and the fact that local parents lacked expertise and confidence the catalyst has been sylvia scott she became director of the local sure start project three years ago when she arrived she found that much of the planning for childcare provision in the area had been decided by health and education professionals after little consultation she established the childrens centre as a mutual society registered with the financial services authority registration proceeds only if the fsa is satisfied that the society has a social purpose then it enjoys many of the advantages of a registered charity including access to the lottery fund once the structure was in place sylvia and her team set about recruiting help we literally walked the streets asking local people what they wanted would this work or that people were drawn into the childrens centre gradually attracted by a range of onestop shop services and a creche on offer aside from the nursery is backtowork training parenting health and social support including access to psychologists and speech therapists and courses in subjects such as baby massage early learning and play now the timetable is packed organised and initiated by parents who also run a cafe on site which provides food for the nursery were not perfect were not utopia says rumsey we have compliments and complaints we dont see things as right or wrong but as constant opportunities to improve what matters is that we are in control and nothing happens behind closed doors

text: women changing to work parttime face an average cut in hourly earnings according to research published today by the department for trade and industry it found women switching from fulltime work were often forced to make a downward occupational shift into lower grade work those able to stay with the same employer or in the same occupation suffered little financially but many were forced to accept a demotion as the price of flexibility in working hours the research by alan manning and barbara petronogolo of the london school of economics found the pay penalty for working parttime in britain was the biggest in europe evidence on job mobility shows that the uk has the highest rates of demotions when women move from fulltime to parttime they said

text: in the primarycoloured nursery at audley and queens park childrens centre in blackburn filled with the smell of eid cakes made by miniature bakers in aprons threeyearold tariq is busy at the building table joining wooden blocks with plastic screws next door in the centres kitchen his mum maherun jogee is cooking meals for visitors to the cafe her first paid job for which she trained in the same building the mix of work training and childcare is just one combination of the impressive range of services available on a single site at audley and queens park one of seven new childrens centres opened in a breathless months by blackburn with darwen borough council with plans for six more under way the judges called this project a clear winner demonstrating joinedup government at its best linking different agencies to improve services for children the onestop centres all also offering outreach services in their surrounding communities form the heart of the unitary authoritys new early years excellence service the approach which preempted the governments own thinking by several years brings together a range of services for children up to five and their families for the first time in the borough bulldozing old walls between education health and social services in an effort to offer truly joinedup provision while local families were once forced to trek between different locations for a child health checkup job advice and training or a library often ending up simply missing out parents like jogee can now find the same facilities and more in one wellequipped either newly built or completely refurbished building close to their home sitting on a mulberrycoloured sofa in the audley and queens park centres vividly painted reception the motherofthree says before this we just didnt have any childcare in this area and because of that nobody could go to work or train so this is ideal i had never had a paid job and i didnt have enough confidence but the staff here supported and helped me like other mothers dropping into the centre she is full of praise for the facilities and opportunities on offer when we come here it is very homely we feel like an accidental family sayeeda mahetar now also in paid work at the centre while her daughter is cared for in the nursery describes how the threeyearold can enjoy facilities including childcare an underfives library and dropin health and child development clinics undreamed of when her older children now aged eight seven and six were preschoolers it was so hard to get on a bus with them all and get to college so there is no way i would be working without the centre the change is down to a new effort to work with families she adds before no one was being listened to but now we are really involved an extensive consultation to discover families real needs was a key part of preparation for the move to the new integrated early years excellence service according to its head gladys rhodes previously she acknowledges services were sometimes provided on the basis of illinformed perceptions of what parents particularly those from the mix of asianheritage communities who make up of the population in some parts of the borough wanted and needed with no effort made to ask the consumers themselves using research already carried out by the five local sure start programmes one of which forms the core of the audley and queens park centre together with more questionnaires and market stalls where parents could give their views the council found the limited availability and high cost of childcare together with the scattered nature of services were key concerns it also emerged that contrary to some preconceptions many mothers were keen to work but were prevented by lack of childcare and the need for training where families are in a cycle of deprivation and poverty there is almost an expectation that they dont know any better whereas actually they bloody well do rhodes says they were not given the choice to have aspiration or ambition the failures in provision were set against a background of high levels of poverty and deprivation in some parts of the borough reflected in poor housing higher than average infant mortality with low takeup of immunisation and child health checks and low educational attainment facilities too were old and unfit one council nursery was originally a cotton nursery established over years ago for the children of millworkers and designed to last only a decade it really felt as though there were huge gaps there says rhodes none of the services joined up for families they had to try and make sense of them themselves the sure start programmes already running in blackburn and darwen reinforced the view that an allinclusive approach provided by a range of agencies working together was the answer that decision though was in some ways the easy part rhodes and her team then had to persuade the authority as a whole as well as other services competing for investment that a focus on early years was the right way forward and then oversee a wholesale change affecting staff the clinching argument for throwing the councils weight and an extra a year towards the services m annual running costs at the youngest children and their families was the capacity to reap longer term dividends by intervening early it was about looking at where we could really make a difference says rhodes we could show people working on youth crime or regeneration that this investment supported what they were doing the process of informing persuading and supporting sometimes wary or reluctant staff was among the toughest challenges in creating the new service it was a gradual process of workshops newsletters and individual interviews for every member of staff rhodes explains we sold it on the basis that families deserved better than we were giving them but there was resistance people felt a real fear of the unknown staff who had always worked with older nursery children were cautious about working with a younger age group for example and those in education had concerns at becoming involved with social services the changeover which has seen every staff member retained on their original terms and conditions is still bedding down but rhodes believes it has succeeded ultimately according to harry catherall the borough councils executive director community and personal the authority took a wellresearched gamble which appears to be more than paying off some of it is scary but the council stuck their neck out and said we will take a risk and establish a network of centres now the government is very interested in what we are doing if ministers want more endorsement they need go no further than the boroughs parents maryam batan a motheroftwo and parent representative at audley and queens park looks proudly round the building whose colour scheme and design she and other mothers helped choose and declares it like buckingham palace runnersup east kent coastal teaching pct s early intervention programme allows midwives health visitors and social workers to work together to detect family stresses and enhance parenting skills quarriers breakaway project in rural scotland provides short breaks for fathers looking after disabled children reducing their isolation and widening support the guardian public services awards overall winner was sponsored by hays public services the service delivery childrens services category was sponsored by zurich municipal

text: why does the financial sector have such a poor record on sex discrimination last week a survey conducted by the equal opportunities commission via the magazine personnel today found that in other sectors an average of one in firms had paid an employee to leave when she became pregnant but in the financial sector the average was one in four furthermore the sector also has far more acrimonious settlements than any other industry on average one in firms has been taken to an employment tribunal over pregnancy or maternity leave in finance the average was one in seven when challenged people in finance usually point to the trading floors as the source of the discrepancy there is some justice in the accusation trading is an adrenalinedriven business whose practitioners have little time to spare for other peoples feelings and since the traders earn the profits they often set the cultural tone for their institutions and rise to power within them although it is still maledominated however women are beginning to prevail at the more junior levels overall the finance industry has had a female majority for about years now since the early s when the gender balance changed and female employees at financial institutions outnumbered the male for the first time ever the change came about as highstreet banks introduced shift work and encouraged former employees who had left to have children to return and work the antisocial hours in the city of london a cultural shift is also underway banks are paying more attention to marketing and customer relations career paths are opening up which allow people to climb the executive ladder without having to pass through the trading bearpit meanwhile trading itself is becoming more computerised and less governed by nerve and gut instinct there is a glimmer of hope that these changes will make a fairer working environment for women

text: i used to be in a relationship in which my partner was physically violent to me why did i stay because i loved him and believed him each time he said it wouldnt happen again it was when he started playing with knives that i realised it wouldnt stop there so i left not as easy as it sounds in time i started volunteering for a domestic violence charity supporting women in similar situations through the training i learnt that it wasnt my fault i didnt have a flaw in me that induced violence and the responsibility was per cent his the charity also ran at a different site a perpetrator programme for men who had been violent to their partners due to a lack of funding the mens and womens services had to be merged into the same building i left the charity outraged as i told the women i supported men never change seven years on i work for a project supporting women in hospitals who have experienced abuse and my fear has gone i no longer have to crouch behind a rail of ski jackets in nike when i spot him in the crowd and i no longer think he is trying to get into my flat at night without that fear my attitude to him has softened while i know it was his choice to hit me and it was wise to leave i also know that he learnt his behaviour from a young age and he hated himself for it and i believe if he had wanted it badly enough and there were services for him to access he might have changed my story is not unusual as we all know from the posters showing the man hitting the women in front of their dinner guests domestic violence is rife think of a gathering of of your female friends statistically one of them will be going home to an abusive partner one in four has been assaulted by an intimate at some point every three days one woman in the uk is murdered by her partner or expartner while there are statistics to suggest men are also at the receiving end of domestic violence the overwhelming majority of victims are female in my work i meet women who time and again go back to their partners even when he has told her quite explicitly what will happen when she does its difficult for someone who hasnt made that decision to understand sometimes women do make the break and the partner moves on to the next victim its only a matter of time before another casualty of domestic violence is added to the statistics in the past years societys response to the problem has evolved the police no longer walk away saying its only a domestic courts dedicated to the hearing of domestic violence cases are springing up there is a domestic violence bill going through parliament to make the law more protective the department of health has just announced that midwives must routinely ask every women under their care if they have been abused now society is starting to look at how to change the root of the problem the violence of the perpetrators perpetrator programmes first came to the uk from the us more than years ago now there are in excess of selfreferring groups and the national probation service is in the process of rolling out two accredited perpetrator programmes respect the uk association for perpetrator programmes and associated womens services was launched in by a group of practitioners who felt there should be some guidance for the new work being carried out and to promote good practice in the field it has also just launched a national phone line for perpetrators funded by the home office it offers information and advice to those who are violent or abusive callers get the unequivocal message that violence is unacceptable staff will help calm the perpetrator if he is upset or angry and will encourage him to seek help to stop jo todd director of respect says its not a helpline for men who abuse its an information line to help men start to take responsibility for their violence our priority is always the safety of women and children but do perpetrator programmes work paul wynn from merseyside probation who is is involved in one of the longestrunning programmes says there is evidence to suggest that perpetrators are more successful in stopping violence than if they are just fined or locked up one study showed that of a group of men who attended a perpetrator group per cent didnt reoffend within the time of the study while men who didnt attend a group had a reoffending rate of per cent while these men are ordered by courts to attend the groups men who selfrefer have other motivations rita who works with women who have managed to leave is sceptical of perpetrator programmes she thinks men use the groups to regain power over women ive seen it loads of times women leave the refuge and go back into the violence because hes said hell attend a course after two weeks hes broken his promise and shes stuck there again one of the dangers of running a perpetrator programme is the implicit message that it gives to women that their partner might change this can give women false hope the reality is that the perpetrator programmes work some of the time for some of the men if a woman reading this believes her partner may change if he attends a programme she may make unsafe choices respects view is that perpetrator groups should never be run in isolation they should always have a linked womens support service in this way specialist workers have regular contact with the woman inform her if they feel shes in danger do safety planning with her and manage her expectations for change paul ellis not his real name a teacher from leeds was physically and emotionally violent to his wife for the seven years of their marriage he believes the group he attends has radically altered his behaviour the first time it happened it took me by surprise it was over nothing she had put coloured clothes in with the whites i was furious when she told me to calm down i snapped i pushed her and slapped her face like most perpetrators paul felt guilty after this initial outburst and tried to make it up to his wife by taking her out for a meal i needed her to forgive me so everything could get back to normal but it happened again anything triggered it anything that made me feel she was disrespecting me it was a cycle id abuse her feel bad then try to make it up to her the guilt would fade and something would happen that i wasnt happy about id give her a warning the first few times but id soon be lashing out again paul remembers the time his wifes mobile phone went off when they were shopping when she didnt heed my warning to put the phone down i told her id sort her out later as i drove home i kept thinking i had to get her to show obedience to me in the house i told her to put the bags down settle the children down in front of the tv then i took her into the other room and beat the hell out of her paul was careful not to let the bruises show i knew where to hit her so that people didnt notice it and if she was making too much noise i would put a towel round her face several years into their marriage after regular beatings every few months paul threatened to crash the car if his wife didnt stop the baby crying it was the first time he had directly threatened the children that night she left the house and never returned paul waited three years for his wife and children to come back one day his solicitor suggested a perpetrator programme paul was now in a new relationship with jane and he hadnt told her about his violence he was convinced he had changed but slowly he started to become picky and controlling and decided he had to tell her the truth and seek help for his behaviour jane says i was frightened and shocked how could the lovely gentle man i fell in love with have done this but i had got increasingly worried about his behaviour i was walking on eggshells he asked me to help him change and i said i would if he got help i wanted to give him the chance when he came back from the group he was shocked by what men did to their partners each week he had to report back about his behaviour and slowly it dawned on him that he was behaving the same way as them but jane cautions if a woman is suffering violence she should leave even if he goes on the course only if he proves by his actions that hes changed should she go back paul has proved to me that hes changed hes able to tell me how hes feeling and he no longer blames me for things that go wrong hes not perfect and he still gets angry but now he knows to walk away from the situation and to take time out the group was made up of men from different backgrounds and with different levels of violence they had one thing in common wanting to find another way to relate to their partner it was weird sitting round in a group and saying how vile you had been but it made it real you can no longer deny it if you say it out loud then you have to face what it must have been like for your partner the turning point for me was watching a video of a man beating his wife up i couldnt drive home because i was sobbing so hard paul and jane are now living together and have a oneyearold baby she concludes i love him and want to be with him he wasnt born angry he grew like that because of his life experiences im not excusing his past behaviour but its something to work with i believe that people can change i interviewed another man for this piece he had been through a perpetrator programme and said he had changed i was so alarmed by the way he was still minimising his behaviour and blaming his partner that i decided i couldnt include it it brought home the point that perpetrator programmes are not a fixall solution eleri butler policy and development officer for womens aid says women will not be optimistic about programmes which may lead them to make unsafe choices thats why womens safety work must be at the heart of it women have said that men use their attendance to carry on the abuse to control them in other ways and to justify their behaviour based on what theyve heard other women say womens aid supports perpetrator programmes if they adhere to respects guidelines and if they are treated as part of a multiagency response its not an either or situation theyve got a place in reducing and preventing domestic violence but its just one part of the large picture when i met my ex i fell head over heels in love i thought id found my soulmate while i now know that this is a common phenomenon with men who are controlling and abusive i wonder what would have happened if hed have known where to get help the first time he hit me if hes still hurting the one he loves i hope hes reading this national domestic violence is a hour helpline for women wwwwomensaidorguk respect phoneline for perpetrators amnoonpmpm mon wed fri and pmpm tuesday wwwrespectuknet broken rainbow for lesbians gay men and transgendered people experiencing domestic violence

text: yesterday a furious fathers rights campaigner handcuffed himself to margaret hodge a citizens arrest he called it just three days earlier the head of the crisisridden child support agency resigned admitting that over the past months the agency charged with collecting child maintenance has made payments to only one in eight single parents most of them mothers it is fitting that both should happen in the same week these two stories of the bungled bureaucratic attempt to make nonresident parents take financial responsibility for their children and of the rise of increasingly militant fathers rights groups have been interwoven for more than a decade when the csa opened in no one was more surprised than the then fiveyearold australian csa theyd known a british csa was on the cards english officials had visited and had returned to london with reams of notes what caused the australians to rub their eyes was not the existence but the design of the british csa it seemed the brits had not only failed to learn from the many positive elements of the australian experience they had done the exact opposite where the australian formula was simple and transparent britains was complicated and obscure where the australians allowed lone parents on benefit to keep more than half the child support paid the uk treasury clawed the lot back where the australians collected money for children only the brits claimed for mothers too where the australians had chosen not to revise existing court settlements the brits had decided to go retrospective in the uk a furore erupted while a relatively moderate divorced dads pressure group families need fathers already existed they had never commanded public attention now faced with the csa a critical mass of men many of whom had been to the right schools and had always assumed the law would be on their side found themselves on the wrong side of an unpredictable apparently irrational badly run bureaucracy they took to the streets and to their mps surgeries fastforward years while the angry dads opposition to the csa in britain has dwindled partly because the agency has been so ineffectual their opposition to the family courts has mushroomed year on year until the separated dads discourse has become the only fatherhood story in town meanwhile on the other side of the world something very different is happening at a glossy dinner in canberra the eightyearsserving chief executive of the australian csa is collecting the australian prime ministers gold award for service excellence international governmentwatchers always caution against transnational comparison they warn that every situation is different and it is true that the potential australian csa clientbase contains fewer poor young unmarried parents than its british equivalent they point out that the australian csa got a rough ride to start with and is still not without its critics nevertheless the australian csas achievements are impressive particularly in comparison with britain it saves its government more money per case than any other countrys even while passing through of all payments directly to children eighty per cent of the australian agencys clients declare themselves either satisfied or very satisfied with the service and in a resounding endorsement of the system of separating australian couples now register with the csa of these more than half end up with private arrangements for the transfer of cash after the agency has calculated the amount private arrangements are the holy grail of child support being associated with greater likelihood of support being paid larger amounts of support being paid greater flexibility over time and benefits in terms of childrens wellbeing and development nor in australia is there a rampant fathers rights movement even though fatherchild contact postseparation is no more substantial than in the uk and fathers when surveyed are no more satisfied with this one reason britains separated fathers make so much fuss outside the system may be that they are neither seen nor heard within it remarkably little research has looked at their experiences and when one report on cohabitation breakdown identified unmarried fathers as doing badly out of the system the foundation that had commissioned the research in effect suppressed the findings by failing to issue a press release separated fathers views are routinely misrepresented government sources imply with a disingenuousness bordering on dishonesty that because of cases never get to court of fathers are satisfied in fact many of these men are very dissatisfied and recently government advisers possibly in an attempt further to discredit the protesters have been citing research they say shows more separated mothers than fathers wanting children to see more of their dads the research method used to obtain these figures is highly unusual whats more they conflict with other findings in the same study and have not been replicated in any other study research from all over the world reveals far more separated fathers than mothers dissatisfied with childfather contact especially where contact levels are low or nonexistent the absence of support for separated dads in the uk is chronic by contrast in australia there is a governmentfunded malededicated helpline mensline and local information and support services to meet the needs of this disaffected group have been given funding priorities the initiatives do not just benefit fathers some innovative pilots fasttrack cases involving allegations of child abuse or domestic violence others look to dissolve intransigent contact disputes through focusing parents attention on their childrens needs the australian government recently pledged considerable resources to develop an holistic approach to family breakdown this will include a national network of communitybased family relationship centres which will siphon off many separating couples long before they get anywhere near a judge but it is in the contrast between the two countries csas that the real gap yawns today the australian agency boasts a culture of voluntary compliance rather than enforcement newlyseparated fathers are targeted before child support arrears build up referrals for help with employment and other issues debtmanagement relationship concerns can be made meanwhile the british csa flails about and like the rest of the system continues to regard separated fathers as nothing more than walking wallets and very unsatisfactory ones at that the select committee were told has recently visited australia again lets hope they get it right this time adrienne burgess is research and policy officer at fathers direct the australian csa will be at fathers directs national conference working with fathers on april wwwfathersdirectcom

text: matt oconnor letters november is wrong to say that everincreasing numbers of decent loving fathers are marginalised or excluded altogether from the lives of their children by the family justice system decent loving fathers either manage to agree contact with the childrens mothers without resorting to the legal process or such contact is invariably agreed at or ordered by the court the presumption of contact is so strong that there have to be extremely cogent reasons why the courts would not permit contact to take place a tiny minority of fathers have usually been denied contact because they have been violent or abusive to the child or mother or for such reasons as serious alcoholism or drug misuse which is having a detrimental effect on the child contrary to what fathers justice says research has shown that most mothers make huge efforts to instigate contact and keep it going many contact proceedings are started not by fathers but by mothers who want to regularise arrangements where they are haphazard my own research revealed that whereas all professionals involved expected the mother to make huge efforts to keep contact going practically nothing was expected of fathers apart from arriving on time for visits i do agree there needs to be more transparency about the process im sure that if more details were publicly known about contact cases we might find that many of the cases relating to members of fathers justice involve allegations and in some cases findings against them of serious violence and harassment of the childrens mothers i challenge oconnor to reveal the number of members of fathers justice who have injunctions against them prohibiting violence or harassment of women andor children finally may i take issue with matt oconnors description of fjs campaign as peaceful if there are any repercussions as a result of this letter guardian readers will be the first to know a barnett london when fathers justice begins to acknowledge the significance of domestic violence and its links with child abuse they may start to acquire some credibility indeed all fathers organisations could play a crucial part in high lighting concern about the deaths of children during contact visits the granting of contact and indeed residence orders to men with records of offences against children and the way that the voices of children so often go unheard in family proceedings those who might have some sort of insight into how a childs right to safe contact with both parents is undermined by the inability of so many men to make good relationships with their children should be able to play a more constructive part in the select committee inquiry than inspiring the sort of security that was necessary for our meeting with elizabeth butlersloss and her colleagues last week hilton dawson mp member constitutional affairs select committee

text: initiatives to bolster the position of women in the boardroom are being planned by the government and the private sector aides to patricia hewitt the trade and industry secretary have held meetings with headhunters over recent weeks the results of the talks with some of the countrys top search and recruitment firms could be announced as soon as next month the department of trade and industrys new efforts to promote female executives come as a fresh attempt is made by the private sector to redress the balance in the boardroom with the launch of a register of women suitable for executive and nonexecutive positions some months after laura dandreatyson the academic and former clinton administration adviser in the united states rejected a proposal to draw up a list of people from outside the corporate sector who would make suitable nonexecutives a management consultant has embarked upon her own attempt to address the situation hilarie owen author of leadership books and founder of the institute of leadership is creating the register of executive and nonexecutive women or renew to provide a headhunting service for large and small british firms she insisted it is not a response to the refusal by ms dandreatyson head of the london business school to draw up the list as suggested by derek higgs in his review of boardrooms which highlighted their white male culture it was clearly in her mind however report after report highlights the low number of women on uk boards were keen to make companies realise that the right director can bring competence skills and experience to a board thereby adding balance to the existing team and strengthening the overall company performance ms owen said a guardian investigation earlier this year of the top companies found that boardroom seats were occupied by women and only were fulltime executives while a report by accountant deloitte found that among the top firms of executive directors are women and of nonexecutives are female just last week the picture in the ftse worsened after the most femalefriendly board in the guardian survey marks amp spencer with four women lost its women executives after a shakeup ms owen plans to launch renew with seminars in london manchester cardiff and glasgow in the coming weeks with a view to creating a network of women who have the potential to go on to boards a few expressions of interest from a handful of women have been received for the register so far she described it as not just a register that she can run as a recruitment firm but also an avenue by which the women can be mentored and developed for the boardroom if her plan works she believes that companies will no longer be able to fall back on the excuse that they would appoint women if only they could find them brian patterson chairman of the irish times and former chief executive of wedgewood pottery is one of renews supporters and will sit on its strong advisory board im against positive discrimination it leads to tokenism as a generality women do bring a different perspective on life on business and on organisations a board that doesnt make use of that is missing something he said the government which commissioned the higgs report after the collapse of enron highlighted deficiencies in boardroom practices in the us has embarked on a number of initiatives to encourage diversity in the workplace the most recent was announced in july when a women and work commission headed by baroness prosser was set up to examine a wide range of issues including the glass ceiling it is scheduled to report to the prime minister by next autumn but only three years ago denise kingsmill the then deputy chairman of the competition commission published a wellreceived review of women at work for the government mrs kingsmill set out a series of aims to help narrow the pay gap and create a mechanism by which companies should be forced to reveal in their annual reports how they treat female employees even so the government is still tackling the issue the dti said patricia hewitt has discussed the role of women in the boardroom with of the heads of the countrys biggest companies in the past year the department has also been in discussions with the headhunters who draw up the shortlists for boardroom positions about the way they approach their task and hinted that an initiative could be on the way fiona driscoll a director of management consultancy hedra and member of the renew advisory panel said she hoped the launch of the organisation would help raise the issue again you cant go well it didnt work last time so we wont try any more she said

ensuring that the most excluded in our society get the same chances as everyone else the prime ministers pledge will help create these chances for disabled children francine bates contact a family jo williams mencap brian lamb special educational consortium christine lenehan council for disabled children as more mothers work and the longhours culture continues in the uk the balancing of the responsibilities of work and family life has become a major issue for todays parents it is vital that parents have a real choice about work and bringing up their children parents are desperate for goodquality affordable childcare and we are encouraged by the governments guarantee of affordable schoolbased childcare not just during term time but year round however we also feel passionately that all families are individual and have different needs decisions made by parents must be valued and supported whether it means they stay at home work parttime and flexibly or fulltime jan fry parentline text: its not often the chancellor offers working parents help with childcare costs but things are looking up for the uks hardworking parents from april gordon brown is extending the childcare voucher scheme to offer working parents income tax relief on the first they earn each week to most people this will be worth a year the only problem is you have to work for a company that has implemented the scheme childcare vouchers are not new its just the way they are taxed that is about to change in his last budget gordon brown announced he was extending their scope to include income tax currently they are restricted to relief on national insurance such plans are known as salary sacrifice schemes and work in exactly the same way as the home computer mobile phone and bicycle initiatives all recently featured in jobs amp money the employer deducts an agreed amount from the employees net earnings which is then passed to the company administrating the voucher schemes on its behalf they in turn provide that employee with vouchers which can be used to pay the registered person or organisation looking after offspring those who now benefit from the scheme dont pay the national insurance on the proportion of their salary they take in vouchers assuming they are standard rate tax payers who pay the average child care costs this saves around a year according to john morton who works for accor services the uks biggest administrator of voucher schemes most basic rate tax payers will be an extra a year better off when the new rules come into force after april basic rate tax payers who take at least of their salary in vouchers will save a year by taking part in a voucher scheme if they are higher rate taxpayers they will save there is no cost to the employee as the admin costs are usually met out of the ni sav ings that the employing company also enjoys he said his company which already offers voucher administration for more than organisations including the treasury and the house of commons is waiting to see how the rules governing nannies will be changed it is intended that vouchers will only be able to be used to pay registered child minders or ofstedregistered nursery schools as well as newlyregulated nannies until now they have been unregulated however the government has said it intends to impose the lightest of regulatory touches to control this important area of the market he said shawn healy tax partner at bdo stoy hayward specialising in salary sacrifice schemes says the most likely beneficiaries will be couples both earning more than until now there hasnt been much takeup among the better paid as there has been little incentive to do so that all changes after april higher taxpayers will be significantly better off and more companies in say the city will be looking at introducing schemes both parents can claim the benefit for the same child on the flipside single parents obviously dont come out of it so well he said sacrificing salary may also affect your entitlement to tax credits several contributionbased benefits such as incapacity benefit rely on minimum ni payments for a small number taking a salary sacrifice scheme may drop them below the threshold similarly maternity allowance is based on your level of income not including earnings sacrificed in this way dummy guide childcare vouchers childcare vouchers effectively let workers work the employer deducts the money from the workers pay packet and sends it on to the company administering the scheme the employee is then sent a voucher which they can use to pay their childcare provider the nursery or childminder registers with the administering company and sends in the vouchers it has received the admin company pays their value directly into the childcare providers bank account most vouchers schemes are paper based but there are some internetbased evoucher schemes the admin charges are usually picked up by the employees company and are paid for out of the national text: elizabeth butlersloss may be irked by the way that fathers justice has brought the grievances of disenfranchised parents and grandparents to her doorstep profile november but she cannot seriously dispute the causal link between our campaign of peaceful protest and her own presence in front of a commons inquiry to answer questions about the family courts she also overlooks the perfectly sensible proposals for reform advanced in our blueprint for family law in the st century presented to downing street in june and included in our own submission to the inquiry equal parenting groups have been lobbying patiently for years and have been fobbed off with a succession of false promises with the result that to quote from a lecture given by butlersloss in april last year of fathers have little or no continuing relationship with their children postseparation since her appointment as head of the family division five years ago butlersloss has presided over what i believe history will come to regard as the most disastrous period in the history of britains family courts and their deathknell this has witnessed everincreasing numbers of decent loving fathers marginalised or excluded altogether from the lives of their children by a secretive and unaccountable system which infantilises parents and fosters conflict between them following divorce or separation all of course in the best interests of our children matt oconnor chair fathers justice

text: its the biggest financial headache for new parents how to arrange and pay for childcare over the past five years the cost of childcare has risen by and the financial gain for mothers returning birth of the baby childcare looks set to become a key battleground in the coming election with labour promising that it will give every parent of primary school children access to childcare from dawn their own fees and any special arrangements unlike nannies they must be registered under the children act with the office for standards in education ofsted and are regularly inspected childminders are normally paid hourly and rates vary around the country for a fulltime place you should expect to pay between and a week according to daycare trusts latest childcare costs figures youll need to discuss text: these are testing times in the family courts angry fathers barred from seeing their children throw condoms filled with purple powder at the prime minister and scale the facade of buckingham palace dame elizabeth butlersloss cant even get away from it all at weekends unhappy demonstrators picket her home and heap blame on her and other judges like her for the systems failure to get to grips with the fallout of shattered relationships as president of the high courts family division butlersloss sits at the apex of the family courts which deal with battles a year between divorced and separated parents over their children in her years as a family judge she says the burden of blame has never been so great she wont meet the militant group fathersjustice she told mps at the constitutional affairs select committee this week as long as they persist in hurling condoms and in besieging her devon farmhouse with a double decker bus complete with loudhailer such stunts she has dismissed in the past as jolly irritating but there is an undercurrent of threat which could unsettle someone less robust a website posting accused butlersloss and the other family judges of crimes against humanity and one pickets poster posed the question if bseinfected meat is bad for kids why is this mad cow in charge of family courts the children act was meant to take some of the heat out of parental battles custody and access with their suggestion of prizes to be won or lost became the more neutral residence and contact but words dont change human nature while most parents manage to negotiate a way through the minefield of postdivorce parenting others descend into allout war as one boy told a social worker it is like a war you know they are fighting and they are fighting over me in when dame elizabeth went on the bench many fathers just opted out of the battle and out of their childrens lives the courts too downplayed the role of fathers in one of the few interviews she has given butlersloss admitted in i dont think we recognised the importance of a child having both parents the way we do now my thinking has certainly evolved the important thing for a judge is never to think you know it all the longer i sit the more i feel i have to learn she is unique in having experienced the system from top to bottom her journey began at the age of as a comparatively lowly divorce registrar followed by promotion to high court judge at and later the accolade of first woman in the court of appeal and the first to head a high court division one of the four top judicial posts in england and wales she was born elizabeth havers years ago into an illustrious legal family her father the high court judge who passed the death sentence on ruth ellis the last woman to be hanged in britain her older brother michael father of the actor nigel havers and the qc philip havers who often argues cases before her in court became a tory mp then attorney general and briefly lord chancellor one of a tiny number of senior judges without a university degree she tried to follow her brother to cambridge but failed to get in took a secretarial course and then read for the bar aged she was called to the bar one of only women among barristers a brief detour into politics saw her stand unsuccessfully as a tory candidate for the safe labour seat of vauxhall in a week before the birth of her first child her daughter frances backwater the irony is that she abandoned her career at the bar for her family but ultimately flew at least as high as if shed stayed the course her father warned her she would have to give up all thought of becoming a high court judge if she took what she called a very nice little backwater job in the divorce registry but he said she had a duty to her barrister husband joe and family her unprecedented promotion from the divorce registry to the high court bench came she believes because of her sex the thatcher government and lord hailsham then lord chancellor were keen to promote women she came to public prominence in the late s when she was appointed to chair the inquiry into the cleveland child sex abuse scandal overzealous paediatricians and social workers had taken children into care within weeks on suspicion that their parents had abused them her report which followed her promotion to the court of appeal paved the way for reforms enshrining stronger rights for parents and children and better interdisciplinary cooperation between professionals in the care system listen to the children was a key message in her report children are people not objects of concern she memorably said and any solution to the woes of the family justice system must recognise that children are not packages but people she told mps this week parents must realise this and put their own power battles behind them there must be a widespread culture shift for everyone involved with parents helped to resolve their own disputes through conciliation and the court seen as a place of last resort she and the other judges are owning up to the flaws in the system tackling the delays trying to make sure a single judge gets a grip on each case and that the family court support service monitors whether contact orders are being obeyed and if not gets the case back to court quickly a pilot to teach warring parents about their childrens needs train them in conflict management skills and help them make their own parenting plans holds out hope for the future hamish cameron a child psychiatrist who has argued for years for such changes sees butlersloss as a progressive and reforming judge who is supportive of fathers jim parton of the moderate fathers group families need fathers says i find her byandlarge very fair to deal with i do think shes reformminded judges and lawyers who have worked with her over the years praise her readiness to listen to the voices of children her sympathy with litigants her determination to get to the heart of the issue and her commonsense she is they say someone who keeps an open mind in one case years ago she had written a draft judgment when she insisted on seeing the boy at the heart of the dispute after talking to him she scratched out what she had written saying i wont go against his wishes cameron who first appeared as an expert witness in her court in the s recalls a care case in which butlersloss decided that children should be taken away from their mother outside court afterwards the mother sobbed im not crying because the children have been taken away im crying because the judge really understood and was so nice to me that quality and the firm control butlersloss takes of her cases were evident in the case last month of luke winstonjones the desperately ill baby with a fatal chromosome abnormality whose mother wanted doctors to try to prolong his life the judge insisted on more evidence about what the cardiac massage the mother wanted as a treatment option would mean for the baby the move prompted the nhs trusts treating him to withdraw their application for a declaration that they need not provide it agonising the most agonising lifeordeath cases to reach the family division usually end up in butlerslosss court she was particularly moved by the plight of ms b a senior social worker left quadriplegic after a blood vessel burst in her neck who eloquently argued for the right to have her life support switched off butlersloss who heard the case at ms bs hospital bedside granted her wish but urged her unsuccessfully to reconsider because she had so much to give at the root of butlerslosss willingness to listen is a strong belief in personal autonomy after a series of cases in the s in which family division judges ruled that doctors could force pregnant mothers to undergo caesareans to save their unborn babies she clamped down and ruled that women who were mentally competent had a right to refuse even at the risk of their own or their babies lives richard gordon qc who represented the woman who won the ruling says of butlersloss anybody doing a right to life or right to die case absolutely knows that shell give that case totally fair and objective consideration shes a very handson judge she has a very clear grasp of the issues that shes deciding shes also a very humane judge what she isnt is a hardedged lawyer life in short born august educated wycombe abbey school she is one of only a handful of senior judges not to have gone to university married joseph william alexander sloss in and they have two sons and a daughter career called to the bar inner temple in and was judge of the high court of justice family division from until in amid the cleveland child abuse scandal and subseqent inquiry that she chaired she became the first female judge in the court of appeal and has been president of the family division since then controversial decisions upholding right of a yearold to have an abortion against her parents wishes and using the human rights act to grant an unprecedented lifetime injunction protecting the new identities of the child murderers robert thompson and jon venables on being a judge the important thing is never to think you know it all the longer i sit the more i feel i have to learn

text: traditional conservative thinking that mothers should stay unpaid at home with their children has been banished forever according to the partys shadow secretary of state for the family in an interview with the guardian theresa may instead outlined her aim to provide choice and flexibility for parents she acknowledged that a new recognition in the party that financial circumstances frequently compel both parents to go out to work and that the state should provide some help with childcare costs was opposed by some grassroots members but she insisted that measures intended to support working parents but also those who choose to be at home for their childrens first year outlined today are strongly supported by the tory leadership and would form a key part of the partys election manifesto as it seeks to counter labours supremacy on childcare issues she said the conservative party has always been the party where it is assumed that we would always be saying to mothers thou shalt sit at home we are not we are saying this is about choice for families the nature of the partys ageing membership made it inevitable that there will be those who lived their lives in a different way and will say we didnt need it childcare help why should anybody else mrs may who was appointed to her newlycreated post within the shadow cabinet in june by tory leader michael howard made clear her view that the conservatives were easily outshone by labour on childcare at the election the creation of a family policy will help the tories convince voters they are in touch with the bread and butter issues that matter to them party strategists believe the conservatives face a tough political challenge however since a battery of reforms have included the creation of childcare places for more than a million children and nursery education places for all three and fouryearolds the introduction of a tax credit to help pay for childcare the establishment of the sure start programme to sup port families in poorer areas and the creation of new childrens centres bringing together childcare healthcare and parental support under its fiveyear plan for education announced in july the government has also promised to introduce in every community an extended school offering care from pm to pm and a childrens centre with more details to be set out in a year childcare strategy expected later this month the conservatives believe they can offer a distinct alternative that meets needs while responding to perceived weaknesses in current policy which they argue offers topdown inflexible solutions mrs may believes the tax credit system designed to help parents pay for britains expensive childcare has proved bureaucratic and complicated the conservatives promise to simplify it and allow parents to use the money for informal care including relatives for the first time the conservatives have promised to keep sure start if elected but are concerned that the scheme sucks staff away from surrounding childcare providers and plan a review prompting suspicions that they would neuter the governments flagship programme mrs may also argues that extended schools may not be the universal answer for childcare saying such services are already running well in churches or other settings in some parts of the country the conservatives she said would take a more handsoff approach leaving more scope for private and voluntary providers the conservative plan will include moves to encourage more grandparents to qualify as childminders which would lead to an emphasis on socialisation many parents are concerned that as the government pilots nursery places for twoyearolds their children are being pushed into education too soon mrs may argues critics of the more marketdriven approach favoured by the conservatives will raise fears that without a governmentled strategy the dream of a nationwide childcare system comparable with those on the continent will never become reality they are also concerned that any move to cut regulation as a means of encouraging expansion could lead to a drop in quality

text: the government is preparing to publish a year strategy for childcare in which for the first time a proposal for its longterm direction will be spelt out new labour has made no secret of the fact that the destination should be goodquality affordable childcare for all who want it in britain universal childcare is one of the few frontiers of the welfare state left to navigate in this respect we have lagged behind other industrialised countries we are some years behind scandinavia which foresaw the challenges presented by more women entering the workforce and took measures to ensure that children were not forgotten amid rapid labour market changes countries from new zealand to the netherlands have also rethought their childcare systems what lessons can we learn from them what does good early years provision look like and how can it best be funded attempts to define goodquality childcare usually rely on quantifiable indicators such as staffchild ratios however experience from other countries suggests that we might do better to reflect on the totality of a childs experience and that the best early years services are based on a childcentred understanding of education one place stands out as offering a standard against which all others can be measured it is not a country but a city young childrens services in the italian city of reggio emilia and the pedagogical theory on which they are based have a worldwide reputation what takes place in the or so centres that cater for children under the age of six in reggio emilia couldnt be laid down in a curriculum or instruction manual their approach is informed by an image of the child not as an empty vessel into which the right ingredients must be poured but as a being with extraordinary potential great emphasis is placed on encouraging curiosity and innovation with both children and teachers engaged in a constant process of discovery the child is not seen as a passive recipient of education or care but as an active participant staff are confident and articulate and parents are encouraged to be involved the outcomes are neither predeterminable nor necessarily measurable but countless testimonies suggest they offer children the strongest foundation for life could such an approach be adopted here the childcare debate in britain focuses on the perceived need to improve early years curricula or to tighten regulation but compared to other countries britain already has some of the toughest regulations we have chosen to go down the route of inspecting out poor quality rather than investing in a highly trained workforce that can be depended on to deliver optimal experiences for children differences in qualification levels speak for themselves to become a danish pedagogue requires three to four years of higher education training most british childcare workers are not required to have passed an alevel and few senior staff hold a degree one thing is certain quality costs no country has managed to develop goodquality childcare paid for entirely out of parents pockets deciding how the costs should be shared is a matter for each society to judge since the s dutch policy has been for childcare costs to be split equally between parents employers and state this tripartite model was born out of a tradition of strong social contracts embodied in collective labour agreements a history that britain does not fully share in denmark federal law prohibits local authorities from charging parents more than of the cost of a childcare place each local authority is allowed to set charges according to parents means within this overall limit sweden by contrast has defined affordability in relation to the proportion of income that parents can be expected to contribute the maximum fee that parents pay is of their income for their first child reduced for subsequent children this would be equivalent to charging parents per child per week a massive reduction on britains typical childcare weekly costs of around but it has taken sweden more than years to get to this point and this level of affordability is unlikely to be achieved in britain within years nevertheless closing the gap between what british parents and their continental neighbours pay must surely be a priority finally what can be learned about building a consensus on an approach to the early years in scandinavia there is such strong public support for investing in childcare that any proposal to reduce the states contribution would be deemed political suicide we are long way from that new zealand whose childcare tradition has been similar to our own perhaps offers more relevant lessons the government there has recently embarked on a year plan to improve the quality of its childcare provision by investing in workforce reform a commitment has been made to achieve a teachertrained workforce by the level of ambition is impressive and it has been matched by an approach to policymaking that is likely to ensure its childcare reforms will not become a casualty of any future political changes the year plan was drawn up following extensive public consultation here too widespread public support will be crucial to the successful implementation of the governments vision for early years provision to meet the needs of the modern labour market and our youngest children lisa harker is chair of the daycare trust infodaycaretrustorguk

text: englands top family law judge yesterday castigated the militant fathers group fathersjustice and said she would refuse to meet them while they persisted in highprofile stunts and demonstrations targeting judges homes dame elizabeth butlersloss the president of the family division of the high court criticised the group whose members climbed the walls of buckingham palace and threw flour bombs at tony blair in the house of commons she said their protests were not sensible and acted against a constructive dialogue between judges and aggrieved fathers who claim the family justice system denies them a fair deal in court battles over contact with their children she was giving evidence with mr justice munby and lord justice wall to the commons constitutional affairs committee which is looking into the reform of the family court system dame elizabeth denied the system was biased against fathers while conceding in written evidence to the committee chaired by the liberal democrat mp alan beith that the present system is open to criticism much of it wellfounded the judge said she had met fathers support groups such as families need fathers and fathers direct and had positive discussions about their cause but she added i cannot meet fathersjustice because they are not being sensible and as long as they throw condoms with purple powder and send a doubledecker bus with a loudspeaker outside my private house in the west country there is no point they are not going to talk they are going to tell me matt oconnor founder of fathersjustice said i am just dumbfounded by a lot of what was said i just think the judges have lost their marbles they are completely out of touch with what i see going on in the courts as a person in litigation the labour mp keith vaz asked whether it was a failure of government that the family court system was receiving such criticism and if judges were being unfairly blamed dame elizabeth replied the judges are being unfairly burdened we are bearing quite an interesting burden of blame i do not think it is the fault of the politicians politicians cannot make the parties be sensible in their oral and written evidence the judges said the systems failings included delays caused by a shortage of judges and the competing pressures of local authority care cases other problems were difficulties in having the same judge see the case through from start to finish lack of resources for mediation counselling and mental health help for problem families and the few options available to make recalcitrant mothers comply with contact orders dame elizabeth and mr justice munby signalled the possibility that family courts where almost all cases are heard behind closed doors could be opened more widely mr justice munby said the reporting of onesided stories without the full facts was doing us serious harm and i dont think the existing rules are necessary

text: on monday gorringe park primary school in mitcham south london became the first school in the uk with a fullyequipped baby unit providing care for infants from three months up to two years and seven months old at the little penguins unit babies and toddlers are cared for by five staff supervised by a trained nursery manager staff are paid from the london borough of merton payroll and are trained to a minimum of nvq level in childcare most have experience of working in private sector nurseries a preopening inspection by the office for standards in education early years department has given the goahead for the school to expand its unit to places the centres facilities include air conditioning cots toilets nappychanging tables play areas and a kitchen an adjacent room set aside for community nurses doctors and health visitors provides a onestop shop for busy parents fees are set at a day although the school does not expect to break even until numbers rise closer to full capacity and there is an added bonus for anxious parents says headteacher alan coode we have installed a webcam so that parents can keep an eye on their babies from their office pc it helps to boost confidence the school has had to overcome difficulties that can arise when mixing statutory provision with what is in effect a minienterprise baby and preschool care must take into account the requirements of the children act and social services departments whereas schoolage children come under the remit of the education act and the local education authority schools that want to open a baby unit must operate it as a standalone business with separate staffing facilities and a dedicated budget the little penguins centre cost to build and equip and was financed entirely through income from breakfast and afterschool clubs a nursery and a holiday play scheme gorringe parks bursar lynn hondorcole says we decided to open our baby unit in response to a huge demand from the local community mainly upwardly mobile black parents where in many cases the wife is attending college being able to leave their children in the schools care from am until pm days a year is popular with working parents keji umoabasi a hospital microbiologist has put her monthold daughter forward for little penguins where she says she would expect to have a onetoone relationship with her daughters carer ive got an older child who goes to the afterschool club so it will mean i can drop both children off at am and collect them at pm

text: you state stand up for your rights minister tells fathers october that the socalled split for contact with children between separating parents as advocated by fathersjustice is backed by the conservatives this is not the case conservatives support a legal presumption of coparenting we believe the best parent for any child is both parents and that both assuming they are fit and proper should be fully involved in the upbringing and development of their child we recognise that government should not prescriptively dictate that a child should be split down the middle but we are convinced that it is impossible for a loving bond to be formed without quality parenting time that is why we believe that parents should have the right to have contact with their children enshrined in law we also believe that without clear guidelines and a greater use of mediation families will continue to suffer the misery of years in the family courts to get too little contact with the children they love as part of a radical overhaul of the family justice system we are proposing to establish proper guidelines so that parents understand what the courts expect of them coupled with early mediation the courts should be the last not the first resort our country deserves a better system of family justice one that is open fair and accountable theresa may mp shadow secretary of state for the family

text: scotland yard wants new laws to force doctors social workers and other professionals to report incidents of domestic violence the move follows research commissioned by the metropolitan police into abuse in the home it showed that in the runup to domestic murders health workers housing officers and others often knew about previous assaults but this information was not shared and the victims suffered a final fatal attack the yard proposal would make it mandatory for professionals aware of such incidents to inform a new risk assessment panel commander brian moore responsible for tackling domestic violence in london explained that multiagency protection panels already monitor the countrys most dangerous people not only sex offenders but mentally ill people with a propensity for violence the bichard report examined how information and intelligence about alleged offenders could be better shared between police forces and other agencies following revelations about the history of sexual allegations against ian huntley the soham murderer but the new risk assessment panel would deal specifically with those committing domestic violence mr moore said this is about protecting people mainly women who may start as victims of violence but can end as victims of murder when we look at some of these cases after the event we find family members neighbours and a raft of professionals all knew what was going on but that information was not analysed or acted upon the department of health is already planning to introduce a policy next year to get doctors and midwives to ask all pregnant women if their partners have ever attacked them but mr moore said even more comprehensive monitoring was necessary we need a statutory regulation to make it mandatory for indications of domestic abuse to be passed on to local panels who will assess it and decide what action needs to be taken some people could be concerned that the victim might not choose to report incidents if the police were to get to hear about it but our research indicates thats not the case the human rights of the perpetrator are outweighed by the human rights of the victim the new panels assessment could lead to swift police action to deal with the most dangerous offenders or anger management therapy for others and timely help for victims but barry hugill director of the civil rights group liberty sounded a note of caution we are in favour of any measure that can help reduce domestic violence he said but once you start trying to collect information and allegations on everyone not only is it a bureaucratic nightmare but what do you do with it you cant prosecute someone unless theyve committed an offence and where there are breakdowns of relationships there are often false allegations would this reduce domestic violence i dont know but it could lead to innocent people being harassed however philippa sully a senior lecturer in interprofessional practice at londons city university who conducted an analysis of five domestic murders for the met insisted that early intervention saved lives she found that in all the cases the violence in the relationships was known about in the family and to various services ms sully said two women die from domestic violence in this country each week we can save lives and if we all work collectively we should also be able to reduce serious injuries to victims

text: womens position in the workforce improved this year but at a depressingly low rate a new report today sex and power who runs britain in from the equal opportunity commission eoc shows a improvement in womens position in business the police and senior legal posts some of senior police officers and of directors on boards of britains biggest companies are now women but as the th anniversary of the sex discrimination act approaches eu states have higher female representation in their national parliaments the proportion in westminster a miserable compares poorly not just to sweden but to scotland and wales as well inequality is inefficient and costs britain dearly selecting leaders in business politics and public life from only half the population ignores the contribution the other half can make girls have been outperforming boys in all key exam stages at school and university for years one way to boost britains low productivity rate is to tap into this pool of talent as competitors have done german productivity is higher frances and americas a massive as an eoc downing street summit on gender and productivity in october documented there are three key causes why britain is not making better use of female labour occupational segregation that locks large numbers of women into lowpaid work of women work in the five lowest paid sectors a continuing difficulty of combining work with caring responsibilities and straight discrimination the first requires reform in schools that would end a skewed curriculum for career advice and the reluctance to challenge occupational stereotyping even the tomlinson report on reforming education for to yearolds missed this challenge the second is being tackled but we are a long way from achieving a properly integrated childcare system the third requires robust monitoring by employers as well as the eoc there are grounds for optimism progressive firms have introduced flexible hours britains skills shortage is forcing maledominated sectors plumbing engineering construction to recruit more women the public sector has a duty to promote equality for women and the new commission set up to find ways of ending job segregation and pay discrimination will report back after the election as the eoc argues everybody should win business from drawing on a larger pool of talent families because of higher earnings society by creating a more prosperous country
