text: nineteen seventytwo was a good year for jonathan gathorneharvey to publish the rise and fall of the british nanny at the time it seemed reasonable to write that the institution and the unnatural relationships it bred were dying winston churchill had far greater feelings of tenderness to his nanny everest than his parents she adored him and called him my lamb when she died churchill said she had been my dearest and most intimate friend during the whole of the years i had lived gathorneharvey looked back on the heyday of the nanny in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and wrote that it wasnt exceptional to find forlorn love the annals of nanny literature are filled with desperate and brutal partings as carer and child were pulled apart by market forces or parental whims by the early s the world in which nannies would shout there are three sorts of sin little sins bigger sins and taking off your shoes without undoing the laces at the children of english upper and uppermiddle classes seemed as dead as the empire the second wave of feminism had yet to roar in and middleclass women brought up their own children the high rates of taxation of the postwar social democratic settlement meant that only families at the top could afford to contract out childcare few workingclass women wanted to lose their independence by becoming livein servants and wouldnt have taken the jobs if they had been on offer a glimpse of a nanny pushing a pram was as rare as the sight of a beggar on the streets today it is the financially egalitarian but sexist s which seems strange the professional couple who draw high salaries throughout their careers has become an engine which wrenches the classes apart the woman and by extension her partner rely on equality between the sexes enforced by equal pay acts antidiscrimination legislation but as sexual inequality has declined inequalities of wealth have shot up and nannies are everywhere keeping the professional marriage in business from john profumo through to david mellor public careers used to be destroyed by scandals about private life it is a sign of the times that the privatisation of private life can now do for them just as well when american activists want to stop the president from giving a plum job to someone they despise they know the best place to start digging for dirt is in his or her childcare arrangements theres a fair chance that they will find wretched ille gal immigrants paid in cash to keep the arrangement away from the prying eyes of the tax authorities the latest victim of the black economy of the wealthy family is bernard kerik a former new york police commissioner who george w bush wanted as his new secretary for homeland security even by the standards of the bush presidency kerik wasnt a shrewd choice the new york papers claimed that the married man had affairs in a flat overlooking ground zero and accepted money from a construction firm alleged to be linked to the mob but it was the nanny who got him he withdrew his candidacy when he had to admit he hadnt checked her immigration status or paid taxes on her wages david blunkett didnt fall because he slept with a dazzlingly cynical married woman but because of the favourable treatment the home office gave her nannys visa application kimberly fortier or quinn as she now calls herself wangled the favour out of blunkett and used his willingness to succumb to destroy him when their affection turned sour everyone agrees that the nanny is at the centre the affair yet she has been barely discussed like many another servant she has been at once essential and invisible her superiors have talked through her as if she wasnt in the room its a pity because it is through leoncia casalme that a local scandal connects to the global scandal of the free market in love casalme is from the philippines and an unasked question is why on earth didnt kimberly fortier and stephen quinn hire a british nanny they could afford one she was the publisher of the spectator and he the publisher of vogue they lived in a million house in mayfair the habitual meanness of the rich could explain it fortier didnt want the passport to make her nannys life better but so she could look after her child when the family travelled to quinns home in ireland but stinginess may not be the whole story casalme gave a stronger lead in an interview with the mail kimberly quinn is the only person i have ever worked for who has made me cry she said she is a loving mother but also a very pushy woman what she wants she has to get and if she doesnt get it she starts yelling and shouting you cant reduce a british nanny to tears too often and hold on to her they have to put up with a lot domestic service is once again work they can and often must do gordon browns employment and benefit policies are based on the notion that mothers from humble backgrounds should leave their children to look after other peoples children its a tough life but as a friend from one of the smarter london postal districts put it to me there are lots of things they wont do they wont cook and clean if theyre not paid to cook and clean and they wont be bullied third world servants are another matter a tradeunion organisers nightmare they are cheaper and more pliable and dont know how to ask for the protection of the law because they live under their employers roof it is all but impossible for outsiders to talk to and help them every now and again charities and pressure groups succeed and manage to break sensational accounts of rape and violence more typical are the stories like that of a filipino nanny ive come across who teeters on the edge of a kind of serfdom first she worked for a middle eastern family in london they locked her in her bedroom at night and searched her when she left the house to make sure she hadnt stolen the spoons she escaped and found what she took to be a progressive young english woman in chelsea the civilised appearance was an illusion she was harried and abused a drop of water on ludicrously impractical teak kitchen surface produced a tantrum a failure to obey the most trivial command produced a screaming fit the nanny was close to a nervous breakdown when she said she wanted to leave her mistress said she would shop her to the home office as an illegal immigrant if she dared defy her she got out anyway and hasnt been pickedup yet she was a small part of a global phenomenon half the worlds migrants are now women they look after the children sick and old of the developed countries while the children sick and old of their own countries fend for themselves earlier this year the american journalist barbara ehrenreich edited nannies maids and sex workers in the new econ omy which rubbed in the sore point that the feminism of the s would have been broken by the insoluble problem of how to combine career and family if domestic servitude hadnt been neatly passed from one group of women to another the book contained many a heartbreaking account of modern nanny everests filipino nannies who leave the children they love behind and fall in love with their temporary charges while their male and female employers liberate themselves from drudgery such uncomfortable reading drew an indignant response critics complained that many maids and nannies were wellpaid and welltreated which is true others said that women were made to feel guilty whatever they did and thats undeniable too in the s when women stayed at home they were accused of lavishing smother love on their sons and turning them into schizophrenics psychopaths or worse homosexuals but the strongest reaction was amused condescension ehrenreich and her colleagues were raging against an economic order which couldnt be changed but just as the order of the s seemed natural to jonathan gathorneharvey so our assumptions will one day seem bizarre while we wait for change it would be good if the constant demands for better childcare could be complemented by demands for better protection for the women who do the childcare and for the leoncia casalmes to at least be recognised as a part of the story

text: its official penguin is the uks top employer for parents on friday the company was awarded the nspcc family friendly employer of the year award beating other finalists accenture loop customer management westfield health scheme and boroughs partnership nhs trust among penguins array of familyfriendly measures are excellent maternity provision generous childcare subsidies and the right for all staff to request flexible working employees are also entitled to days compassionate leave for days when children or parents get sick and they have access to a parents forum which provides mutual support network most importantly for martin dunford the publishing director of the rough guides penguin encourages new dads to take four weeks paid paternity leave it makes a huge difference when your child is born to be able to spend quality time with them he says in fact it seems incredible to me that for many people and not so long ago for everyone theres an expectation to return to work the next day while some of penguins policies are new the family friendly culture is not insists susan taylor hr director at penguin group uk it all started years ago when penguin was founded the company wanted to attract and retain the best people and saw an opportunity to achieve this through providing genuine opportunities for worklife balance the benefits are huge she says parents and kids get to spend more time together not just when they are small but for special events like concerts sports activities medical checks or when they are ill meanwhile we have great staff retention improved customer relations low absenteeism and improved productivity operations manager roz hitchcock is one of the of women at penguin who return to work after maternity leave having taken six months fully paid maternity leave and a further months unpaid after my first baby i asked to move parttime and shortly afterwards got a promotion she says i then took maternity leave for my second child and again theres a feeling that if i wanted to change my hours i probably could coming a close second at fridays award ceremony was boroughs partnership nhs trust which was highly commended by the nspcc like other nhs trusts boroughs offers employees a wide range of flexible working options but more uniquely it has set up an older childrens school holiday activity scheme to support childcare provision for to yearolds this agegroup often see themselves as being too old for childcare points out gail nicholas worklife balance manager at the trust but in regular feedback they have been exceptionally positive about the scheme we find that some staff only need to use the service which is available from am to pm for a few hours a day but young people ask if they can come for longer she says one parent was asked by her child not to take any leave during the holidays which was about the best feedback i could get particularly considering the original resistance of some of the young people all activities are planned in partnership with the young people to ensure that they are varied and focus on their interests recent examples include canoeing rock climbing and an olympic week ms nicholas says parents no longer have to worry about their offspring while theyre at work and the trust as well as its patients benefit from happier more motivated staff i see the scheme as a longterm recruitment tool too she adds these young people are at the age when theyre considering career options and we are able to offer them work experience opportunities detailed consultation with employees is the key to introducing the right initiatives according to loop customer management one of the finalists for the award as a result the company now provides flexible working options including termtime working as well as grandparents leave and life opportunity leave which enables people to take a break when something special comes up such as starting a family or going on a major trip its also important to listen to individual requests loop believes one employee whose son secured a place on a wellknown premiership youth football team changed her hours so that she could take him across the pennines in the afternoons for training sessions with probably one of the bestknown clubs in the world meanwhile at westfield health scheme another of the finalists familyfriendly measures include childcare vouchers operated via a salary sacrifice scheme and a bonus for staff when their baby is born this and other initiatives have won the organisation a good reputation a benefit that accenture also points to accenture allows staff to work from home on fridays as well as offering support with childcare expenses and working parent seminars the shortlisted employers are inspiring examples of how familyfriendly work practices not only benefit working parents but also make good business sense says charlie monkcom the nspccs employment policy adviser if recent research is anything to go by the bigger picture is not so positive however the equal opportunities commission recently found that more than four in uk workers are unaware that parents have the right to request flexible working they also found that almost of those who know what their rights are felt sure that any request would be turned down but rebecca clake adviser at the chartered institute of personnel and development believes this is misleading one of our studies found that the vast majority of requests are accepted indicating that peoples assumptions may be wrong she says there is every reason to believe from our own studies that companies are increasingly realising that they need to offer familyfriendly policies to attract and keep hold of talent

text: hundreds of thousands of families could benefit from a government move to extend childcare tax breaks to help working parents pay for nannies childrens minister margaret hodge said yesterday from april next year families earning up to a year will be able to claim financial support worth up to a week for childcare in their own home providing the carer is registered under a new childcare approval scheme at present the cash help paid as part of the working tax credit is only available for childcare outside the home in nurseries or with childminders leaving many families whose working hours require different kinds of care excluded from the benefit ministers at first resisted paying towards nannies and au pairs amid concerns over how to guarantee quality but they have now opted to introduce a light touch scheme which means carers need only pass police checks gain a first aid certificate and complete a hour induction course if they have no relevant childcare qualification in order to join an approved register ms hodge stressed it would still be up to parents to vet carers coming to their home to look after children there will be no cash support for relatives such as grandparents who look after children although that is the preferred choice of many parents amid government concern not to subsidise existing free arrangements the new nanny tax break coming into force around a month before the expected general election represents an attempt by ministers to ensure moves to improve britains inadequate childcare provisions include universal benefits as well as highly targeted initiatives focused on deprived areas the government is conscious that its much heralded year childcare strategy published last week must be seen to offer a better deal for all parents if claims of a new family friendly welfare state are to be justified speaking during the sure start annual conference in london ms hodge said the strategy was nothing short of a childcare revolution the government did not know how many families would take up the tax break for childcare in the home she said but predicted hundreds of thousands would benefit while cash for nannies will be viewed by some as a preelection windfall for the middle classes childcare in the home is also frequently the only choice for shift workers unable to fit around standard nursery hours anne longfield of the childcare campaign group children said there is a real need for this help among hundreds of thousands of parents but in the past they have just clunked around the system parents want childcare in the home because they feel more secure they dont want to move their children around and they cant find care outside that fits in with their hours the childcare approval scheme will effectively create a register of accredited carers for whom parents can claim tax breaks nannies who must be over will have to pay every year to join the scheme being administered by nestor primecare services a private health and social care employment agency it is expected that many parents will end up paying the fee themselves the tax break scheme will be operated by the inland revenue which yesterday said it text: this week in the wake of the west ham mp tony bankss decision to retire at the forthcoming election labours national executive is expected to ask the constituency to select a candidate from an allwomen shortlist this device used for most seats where the sitting mp has decided in the past year to retire guarantees more women safe seats something that readers of our frontpage story today about the treatment of women mps might think is sensible it is to put it mildly not a universally popular policy but the party decided to face down its critics for a limited period to redress the balance between women and men and as a result it seems certain that as long as its vote holds up it will break the record for women mps many more of them will have comfortable majorities and be able to work with confidence on a career in parliament contrast this with the conservative record philosophically and constitutionally unable to intervene from the centre the party is attempting to reform the selection process with slowburn improvements such as educating local selection committees and introducing a framework of competences by which each candidate must be judged regardless of gender or whether their life experiences match those of the selection panels own children the party boasts that it has already achieved a record number of women candidates yet in the dozen or so of the muchreduced number of safe seats that have come up since only two women candidates have been selected gillian shephard virginia bottomley and marion roe will all be succeeded by men there is increasing frustration both among the women who cannot breach the closed and anxious world of the local tory constituency association and in central office in london where some senior figures fear the party is selecting replicas of failure it is not lost on them that one of labours early steps to electability was to centralise control of the selection process such a step would require reforms as dramatic as those of the s it would almost certainly take a third defeat to give the modernisers the authority to impose it centralised control of candidate selection is not a universal good it risks turning mps into clients of their party hierarchy rather than servants of their constituents and independentminded monitors of government but as a demonstration of a partys willingness to change and text: the early years world got more than it had hoped for yesterday when the government unveiled its year childcare strategy in the chancellors prebudget report an extension of paid maternity leave the option to share leave between parents an extension of free nursery provision for three and fouryearolds a commitment to improve the quality of the early years workforce these proposals are all welcome and the government should be congratulated for its continued commitment to this agenda but the biggest celebration should be reserved for recognition within the strategy that early years is first and foremost about children and families and not the labour market since the introduction of the governments first childcare strategy in three separate objectives have become entangled in the conversation about services for the very young developing the life chances of children with particular stress on the least welloff improving the balance between work and childcare for working mothers and allowing more women to reenter the labour market these are all laudable aims but they are not the same and they are only complementary up to a point when the prime minister tony blair addressed the daycare trust last month his speech was about flexibility for working families and about the life chances of children yesterdays strategy sets the record straight acknowledging that the needs of children and families cannot be compromised in pursuit of labour market objectives the two must be advanced together while much of the strategy does just that there is one aspect that should cause us concern childcare for three to yearolds will continue to be funded through the childcare tax credit so far the childcare tax credit has not succeeded in either of its objectives to create affordable childcare for parents and to make disadvantaged areas more profitable for providers the increase in the subsidy available to parents will help but it will not do enough to reduce the burden of spending on childcare on parents parents spent bn on early years services in almost the same as the amount spent out of public finds bn according to the strategy the increase in the childcare tax credit will reduce the parental contribution for childcare from of total costs to for a family earning a year meanwhile parents in the eu contribute on average only of the total costs of care access to high quality provision relies too heavily on parents ability to pay the inadvertent consequence of this is that childcare is weakest where it is most needed the low level of demand in poor areas means provision is not viable or sustainable childcare places were created between and but closed these tend to be in the places where the gain to children could be the greatest ethnic minority lone parent and lowincome households are least likely to use formal childcare of asian parents used registered childcare in compared to of white parents an approach predicated on improving life chances would suggest a reduction in the level of parents contribution in favour of greater public funding for providers bringing parental contributions down to average eu levels would cost in the region of bn according to estimates by accountants pricewaterhousecoopers this dwarfs the m that the government has set aside for a transformation fund to improve the sustainability of childcare places but well within the course of the year strategy the costs would start to be balanced out by the economic benefits of more women in the labour market by greater output and by a reduction in child poverty the original welfare state largely ignored families for the first five years of a childs life neglecting important opportunities to promote life chances if early years provision is to become a new frontier of the welfare state for the st century we must remove parents ability to pay as a criterion of access the governments longterm ambition to reduce further the proportion of childcare costs paid by low and middleincome families must be a more immediate priority philip collins is director of the social market foundation and vidhya alakeson heads the foundations research into early years and life chances
